div.p: THE REFORMATION. A COMEDY. ACTED At the Dukes Theater.
div.q: Sunt, quibus in Satyra videor nimis acer—
div.p: LONDON, Printed for William Cademan, at the Popes-Head, in the Lower walk of the New Exchange in the Strand, MDCLXXIII.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: I Smile to think how every One that's here,
Expects Tartuffe or Scrupple should appear;
Who with Religions Twang and Mouth a-splay
Should Conventicle now instead of play:
But 't is the other house, you've lost your way.
Here's nothing like a holy Reformation,
Nor Drum, nor Trumpet, though so much in Fashion
In all admired Playes of th' new Translation.
Nay can you Guess what our dull Rogue should mean?
He ha's not left us Room for Gaudy Scene;
Which uses to amuse you for a time,
Whil'st Non-sence safely glides away in Rime.
I'le swear I had advis'd him for the best,
To Lard it with fat Song or bawdy jeast
Or write in Verse and huffe the Gods at least.
But he was humoursome and bid me say,
He was for plodding in the Antient way:
Yet he would if this did not please our Friends,
In Rime and Non-sence strive to make amends.
If we procur'd Noise, Clothes, Scenes, Songs and Dance,
His Siege, or Conquest he can have from France.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: BUT that I know thee honest, I could not guess thou had'st a less design, than the betraying of this Town of Venice to the Grand Seignior.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Or, since thou hast such an opinion of my honesty, what do'st thou think of the retaking Candy?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In earnest Pedro, thou hast been as musing this two hours, as a Polititian would be thought to be, when he thinks of just nothing; sometimes you stand cross arm'd, or biting of your nails; by and by nod, as if it was concluded: then on the sudden scratch your head, as if some prodigious accident had ruin'd the conquest of the Indies.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I am pleased it affords you mirth Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What a Divel ayl'st man? if it be want of Wench or Money, (as I'me sure thou can'st have no other cause of Melancholy) thou hast lived long enough, one would think, to purchase confidence to tell thy Friend.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Thou'rt sure to guess right, without being thought a Conjurer, nay you might have left one of them out too, for
Heaven send me money, and i'le never throw a way a thought, on any thing that's Woman; whilst I know how to purchase them from a Ducat upwards.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But it may be you are grown particular; I have known as brawny a Donn as your Worship, that has shrunk to the thinness of a Bul-rush, in less than two months time, for this thing cal'd Woman, that you talk of.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Certainly thou hast a better opinion of my understanding; particularly as the world goes now? Why Antonio, I tell thee, I will sooner turn Pimp to a Suburb Bawdy House, where there is nothing to be got, but blows, dead Wine, and the Pox: or Hermit, and forswear the sight of them, another extream, and as great a punishment, as—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not so fierce, good Pedro, it must be money then.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Yes faith, I was thinking, since my Father will not be so civil as to dye, what I shall do to live.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He begins to grow a little rude now, that's the truth on't, I had one, thank my Fortune, that came to his Estate betimes, kept it till his Lease of one and twenty Years was run out, and never thought good to renew.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That was kind, but mine's fourscore, yet thinks as little of Death, as he did at fifteen: and o' my conscience is as far from it; nay that that vexes me I can't rest for his rules of temperance, and I know not what, and how he lived when he was a young man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pox o' their Morals, when they are once past pleasures themselves, they envy us. They ne're consider should we all live, as they do now, the World would be undone, I tell thee Pedro, if it were not for this debauchery, that kicks up our heels in convenient time, it would not hold half of us.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: It would be pleasant, but to hear what cunning contrivances I had to live in my Melancholy fit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Will you give me leave to guess? I'le lay my life gaming was the first proposal.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Right, and concluded on, till I considered there was never a Scriveners Clerk, or Taylors Prentice about the
Town, but understood the trade; nay more, the very Women get it, and cheat with as much confidence as a Hec. that has but one stake left, so that design was ruin'd: my next was a Souldiers Life.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The certain retreat of a broken Gamster.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: But methoughts it was a little undecent for a man of my Quality, to walk the Street with one Leg, it may be never an Arm, and half a Nose.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou never thinkest how people would be concern'd for thee; one that so proper a Gentleman should not be able to carry his Drink to his Head, the Women that your dancing was spoiled; besides the Honor Man.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Pox on't, That signifies just as much as Peoples Pitty, when one's certain of hanging: I'le have none on't: next I was for Poetry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why what could put that into thy Head? that's the high way to Beggary.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Not as the World goes now: Besides, believe me, it is an easie Trade to one that understands a modern language or two, and will translate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay hee must rime too, or the Ladies wil nere be pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Phu! That's but a weeks practice at Crambo, and once obtain'd saves us pains: for 'tis impossible to write non-sence in't, some few long words, and half a score sentences out of Seneca's Tragedies, make an Heroick Poet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, thou hast more wit than to think on't, never trouble thy self, thou shalt want nothing whilst thy Father lives; and when he dyes, I know it all secure.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You are still my Friend. That that vext me was to see that Rogue Pisauro, thrive by Air, wear his Jewels, variety of Cloths, keep his Lacquais, Horses, play as deep as any man, and all this out of nothing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It must be some Woman, the little Rogues are grown so loving since these Wars, and want of men, that they begin to take it ill to be courted, and provide for themselves.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I could nere discover't, he's as private as a Confessor.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.p: And upon the same account, for he gets money to conceal her vices: nay your Confessor is like him too in this, that he seldome hides the Womens faults, but in the same time he saves his own credit. But if it be a Woman, much good may it do him, I shall never envy him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nor I, He had better thrash, or be chain'd to the Gallyes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No more, here he is.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Save ye Gallants, I interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No Pisauro, we were just now guessing how thou did'st to live.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Faith Gentlemen ye are both my Friends, but we Chymists always conceal our great secret by which we thrive.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Heaven send the Furnace where you make your gold, don't prove too hot for you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But why in this Garb? thou usest to outshine the Sun.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: I am sorry Gentlemen you have hit upon two Questions, I must be so uncivil as not to answer; but hereafter when things grow ripe..

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: There needs no excuse Pisauro.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Your design goes forward with Pacheco?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, yes I intend to carry Pedro thither,

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: And 'tis odds but I'le bring a Friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Dost think the Women will come in?

sp.speaker: Pis
sp.p: Nere fear't they'l not stand out at any thing that makes for pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: These are mysteries Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'le unriddle all as we go.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Wee'l all meet anon, for the present I must leave you, and to a patient, though I think he is past cure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What's his Disease prethee, that thou art turn'd Quack?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: The Gentile one i'le warrant you, he cures that by his own experience.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: No Faith worse, he's taken o'th' sudden with a love frenzy, and runs mad for a Wench.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pox on him, get him one then.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: That will not do, I have offer'd him as fair as any one, but he is come to his Sonnets, and Serenades, sighs and walks with his Hat over his Eyes in deep meditation of doggrell love verses, calls her by fine Romantick names, sometimes she is Celia fair, then Phyllis, Amarillis, Clelia, and the Devil and all, but her right name, and that I am now going to learn.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Prethee give him a little Ratsbain, or some cold Poyson to cool his pluck; in love; I thought the World had learn't more witt above this 12 month.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: May we know the man?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: I'le try but one Medicine more, and if that cure not, deliver him over to be baited: In the mean time if you chance to guess, pray conceal it till the game grows hot. Gallants adieu.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Adieu Pisauro. Come Pedro you won't fail.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I wish she were return'd, for I'me impatient till I hear some news, Heaven send shee meet him, and me rid of this fond Husband. I am as weary of him, as a Woman can be of a Man, she has married for money; I think I hear her.
Oh Lelia did you find him? and will he come?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Yes Madam,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But art sure he said so? for thou art so apt to forget.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: As sure Madam as that you long for his coming.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Did'st remember the hour too?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Lord Madam what makes you so mistrustful? I did, if you'le have me swear—

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No I believe thee, prithee Cozen pardon me, and think what a sorment 'tis to want the thing we love: Alas, now 'tis a whole long Week since I saw him: and besides, all the while to be troubled with a doating Husband, would make any body impatient.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Is kindness troublesome? I thought no Woman had complain'd on that side.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: O more then any thing, from one I cannot love.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Pray Madam why did you marry then?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Poor innocent, do'st think that love's the only cause? there are a thousand stronger Lelia, that's the very last, in any Womans thoughts, that's wise.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Pray instruct me then, it may be my fortune one day.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I will and dare with confidence since I know thee private. Before I married people flatter'd me, or else they thought me fair, and that little beauty Lelia, was the greatest of my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: and trust me Madam, a very great one too.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: As it was, it proved of strength to tempt Lysander, who was, and still continues, one of the richest Merchants of the Town: my Parents thought the Match so great, that it was in vain for me to seem unwilling: to be short, I married him, but not for love Cozen, but to maintain my Dear Pisauro, who long before had ransackt all my Virgin Treasure, and still enjoys my heart.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I shall endeavour to learn Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Trust me Lelia, no way's so direct to Misery as to marry one you love. Love added to a Husbands power, makes him perfect Tyrant; now let him do or say his pleasure, all's indifferent.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: But is it not as much trouble Madam, to doat on your Gallant?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No Lelia, He has dependance on me, and all my happiness is, I know his fortune's low; Oh! that he were but here once dearest Pisauro.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Here's your Husband Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Then I have a new Trade.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Come Dearest, I must take leave; what weeping? Thou hast too much love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: If I had thought I could have loved so well, I never should have married sure, scarce a Week but I am left to misery and solitude, methinks I could curse him that e're invented your profession.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Brave Woman thou shalt instruct all our Sex.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Chear up dearest, 'tis but for a few days, and i'le return, and love still more, if possible.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A day's an age to be from one I love, nay my mind give's me, you'le nere come agan, stay but one day.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Heaven send he does not take her at her word.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Fond Rogue, my word's engag'd, I cannot for a World.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No you'le nere do any thing I ask you, stay but one hour, come prethee do, let this beg for me.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Rarely acted, she might deceive an Angel.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Why if I should thou'lt be the same then, and trust me, my time is gone, nothing in the World should tempt me from thee, but my credit, prethee Dear be patient.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I have no other remedy, you are always thus cruel, if you find me sick, or dead, when you return, it will never trouble you.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Come prethee be not so unkind, thou know'st I love thee, thou mak'st me weep to hear thee talk thus.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Loving Cuckold! you would have cause, if you knew all.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Well if we must part for ever.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I tell thee 'tis but a day or two.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Farewel, Heaven prosper you, I must have the last look.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: No prethee go, or else you hinder me. Lelia wait on your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: One kiss more, I'me all obedience, and then—

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Adieu dearest.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: One look more. Was't not rarely acted Lelia?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: To the life Madam.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: She's gone, and faith now I begin to think my self a Wretch, to abuse her thus. How easily their good nature is deceived? poor doating fool! I dare swear she loves me, then why should I dissemble thus with her? but hang't let her go, she's but a Wife, and that's enough to fully all her worth. I'le to Emilia and there forget her: if I can get loose, I may return a day or two the sooner for this kindness.
sp.l: But when a Mistress draws, a Wife must wait.
Your Fishes alwaies choose the freshest bait.

sp.speaker: Lel
sp.p: He's gone Madam, He had a grievous conflict betwixt love, and business, talkt a little to himself, gave a kind look or two this way, and Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A fair riddance, Poor Fool▪ now he's as secure of my love, as he is of being Cuckold. Well men may talk of their wisdom, conduct of affairs, &c. but this one Womans vertue of dissembling, out-weighs them all Lelia.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: True Madam, were we all as great proficients as your self.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Tis but getting a husband to Practice on, and thou'lt soon learn. How do I look to day Cozen?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Tempting fair.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: I would be drest to all advantages, for every time I meet Pisauro, methinks I make a new conquest. Prethee what did he say to thee?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Hee talk't something of a Reformation was design'd very much for our advantage, I did not well understand him, but you'l here all anon.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: I wish▪ he were here once, is't not the hour yet Lelia● I'le meet him, if he comes not quickly, if we chance to miss, he has the key, and knows where to expect me.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Hee'l be here Madam presently, pray be patient.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: To me even time it self does slowly move,
There's no such thing as patience in Love.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Mariana, Ismena, hey days! go seek'em out.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: They'r not within, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Not within Sir? This 'tis! Women? I had rather have 40 Cats to look after; and they all wild too, great, wild, Hee Cats. I've seen Tygers, Lyons, Wolves coopt up, and tam'd: But let any man prove to me of his own knowledg, two Women that were so, and i'le believe all Mandevile. O' my conscience I had all bedlams put together in me, when I got these girles, they make nothing of creeping through Key holes.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: They'r only gone to Church Sr.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: To Church Sr? what have women to do at Church Sr? can't they say their Prayers at home, or let them quite alone, and mind their needles? I tell thee there ne're comes any good of these holy pretences; were I young I'de as soon marry one out of the stewes as one of these religious gadders: and the truth on't is it comes much to one, for they meet with Priests at both places. Where's Pacheco?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Abroad Sr.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: There's a youth too, hopeful enough till this cursed voyage: if any man longs to spoile a son, let him send him into England with an Embassadour. They are all mad there, and hated the very true Religion, because of Nunnerys and Covents, that confin'd People to Sobriety and Chastity. I have a hopeful brood; would any thing but the down-right divel had'em.

So, are you come gypsyes? not a word, I've rayl'd my self weary at present, get you in, I'le but take a turn i'th'
gallery, to recover a little, and you shall have it with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What shall we do sister, my Father's strangly angry?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Why e'ne go abroad again, and run for't, or let him talk out his talk, hee's old and quickly out of breath.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: We women are most miserable creatures sister, brought up at first by some severe Parent, or kinswoman; and when we grow most sensible of bondage, deliver'd over to the tyranny of a cruel husband.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Or clap't into a nunnery to spend our lives in thinking, and contemplation, though I perswade my self there's little of religion in't: but from the small remembrance we have of men, scratch their pictures on the walls, and wish: and the first opportunity we have of being sick make use of the confessor.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Thou'rt a wild wench, will nothing tame thee?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: 'Twould make a dog wild to be tyed up thus, I wonder we can never muster courage up for to rebell. I have read of women that have been famous for't, and I'm perswaded I my self have courage enough to be a general.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Brother talkes of some design he has, I wish he would compleat it once.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Were I but a man I'de make my self renown'd in the womens quarrel, work them all deliverance; and then share the best of them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis the mens interest to keep us thus enclos'd Ismena.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: None but but a few elder brothers that are husbands Mariana, I dare swear were it once proposed the young rogues would dye in our defence, 'twould make their addresses cheap and easy, when as now twenty fees can scarcely purchase a good look, which falls hard upon the younger brothers. You'r Melancholy Sister.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I dread my fathers anger, and the very thoughts of liberty torment me worse, then this imprisonment. Would my Brother would come home once, that we might hear the news.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Dread! I'me asham'd to hear you name it, let's in and laugh, and weary out this tyranny.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis thy mirth that keeps me still alive.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Come wench,
sp.l: Our bodyes by a father are confin'd,
But there's no man can rule a womans mind.

div.head: Scena Quarta.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: No news of Lysander?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: No Madam.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: I have not lost my beauty yet, the same lustre sparkles in my Eyes; and youth sits smiling on my cheeks: the same brisk heat runs through my veins, and makes me warm, and active in my love. Then why should he grow cold? Five days and not see me? 'tis very strange! He's too wise to have the dotage of a wife seize him. No, 'tis another love grown happy by my ruin. I'le find out some new way to sound him, for 'tis fixt. My youth must not be lost in this indifference. Lucia bid them bring me in a Chair and Table, and do you fetch me the Prayer-book lyes in my closet.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: The Play-book Madam?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: No the Prayer-book, are you Deaf?

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: You'd better have the other Madam, that will but make you melancholy.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Goe I say, it may be I resolve to be so.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: I shall have a sad trade on't if it comes to this once. I wonder who invented these grave Books! or ever taught any of our profession to read them, I'me sure they'r very much out of our calling.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: It shall be so, and if this fail, I'le find some other way to live; there are more kind men than one.

div.stage: Enter Lucia, gives her the Book.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.p: Here Madam, but I hope you are not in earnest.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Peace Baggage, and if Lysander come, tell him I'me not to be disturb'd.

div.stage: Sits down and turns over the Book.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Since you are so serious, you shall have none of my Company: I'le e'ne go sing a brisk song or two i'th' next room, and bless the first man that comes to put you out of this humor.
Oh here's Lysander, then I must run for't.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: He's come, now all that's woman help me to dissemble. Yet I can find no Prayer that's fit for me. Sure never any woman was so wicked.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Come Emelia throw away thy book, and fly to my embraces, thou need'st not study any new charms. Come let me see what 'tis that tempts thee thus: some smutty Novells on my life. How's this? A Prayer book! I should sooner expect to see the French King turn Calvinist than to find thee in this posture. What sad affliction has brought thee to this misery? Hast spotted thy new gown? lost thy little dog? or dost want a new fashion'd pair of Pendants? Prithee tell me.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: No, No, Sr. None of these. But I have spotted all my life, lost my innocence which you have rob'd me off; and want a new heart▪

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Hey day! turn'd Canter? this becomes thee worse than fine dress, and youthful cloths an old woman: There's scarce a Nun will talk thus through a grate.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: But I shall when I'me there (as I resolve I will) and if I can, teach you repentance.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Pox o' this wheadle, I see through it, and will cure her by one as extravagant.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: It is but Just I help to wash away your guilt, who have been the unlucky cause.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Now for my trade. Oh Emilia from this minute I'me happy: give me your hand, my bloud's obedient; and I can touch thee now with as chast thoughts, as Virgins pray.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: If this be real, I'me undone, but I must on.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Methinks I loath my former life. Oh could we but call it back Emilia.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Then we were blest indeed. But since that cannot be, I'le double all my Orisons, and that way make up my arrears: And never speak, or think of man, but when I put up prayers for you, O Lysander.
— Hang me if I can hold for laughing: if I make a good end of this, if I ever undertake to Preach again, may I turn Nun in earnest.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: She will out-do me; they have th' advantage of a voyce for whining, but I'le try. I'le to a cloyster too, for 'tis but just the residue of life be spent in punishing this too much pamper'd flesh. There in our several cells we'll fast, and watch, and wash away our guilt, and when we're fit to dye remove to heaven. Oh Emilia!

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: This is counterfeit too, but how to come off I can't imagine. Well, dear Lysander (for now I dare call thee so) since our designs agree, let's time our Prayers, that Heaven may hear us both together.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: We'll rise before the morn.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Out-watch the pale-faced moon.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Nor eat to satisfie our appetite, but lengthen out our lives for our devotion.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: We will not drink, but what our tears have season'd.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Nor sleep.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Nor think.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Nor dream.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: Nor live.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Nor any thing but—

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.stage: They both burst out a laughing.
sp.p: I can hold no longer.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Nor I by heaven. You idle rogue, could you imagine I could think thee in earnest?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: I was once half afraid that you was, till I consider'd how ill it became you.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Now what amends for all this? Will you never leave this jealousie?

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: You shall find that within. I did it only for to try you after your absence.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: No more of these tricks, there needs none, I am as fond as ever, come let's in and enjoy our selves, and some twenty years hence, we may venture on such a discourse in earnest.

div.head: SCENA I.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: YEt you resolve to have this wench?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Why I'me sure thou wouldst not have me dye, if it were only to save the trouble of praying for me.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Faith it would put me a little out of my road, that's the truth on't; but why must you needs dye? Thou hast not seen her above twice, and that at Church too: if you had been at your appointment you might have avoided such temptations; for my part I'me resolv'd to keep out of harms way.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Away you're profane.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Prithee stay till thy Saint's Canoniz'd, before thou say so; do you think it religion to kneel squinting at your mistriss, two or three hours with your beads in your hands; and only cast up your eyes, because she's i'th' gallery above you?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: Heaven made such beauty for to be ador'd.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: And she'l make use of it for to be whor'd
sp.p: Why don't you go on? I thought you had a coppy of verses on it. Heaven made &c. I shall believe you are in love, when once you talk your sublime nonsence. Heaven, Beauty, Fate, Adoration, Sun, Divinity and a few such words will make thee Poet too, and then thou'rt fit to court a Queen.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p:
I was bewitch't to tell you, I knew you would but
mock at my misfortunes; I should hardly serve Pisauro so.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Misfortunes do you call it? will you make me believe women can run through thee, like lightning, and set what brand upon a heart they please? Let me be thy Doctor and prescribe thee two or three of my infallible cures against this witchcraft of love. Feed high. Wench discreetly. And go to bed with a jolly cup. Probatum est— 'tis as infallible as the Jesuites powder for a Quartan.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I see I must find some other friend to help me in my affaires. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: I'le be serious. By my troth I had such a qualm came over me once, 'twas troublesome, and lasted about a quarter of an hour, but since a she friend of mine taught me to draw the humor downward, I'me free.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I have no patience to bear this fooling.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: I have done, pray pardon me; but which way do'st thou intend for to obtain her? The old man keeps her with more care, than he does his gold; He cut of a dog's ears t'other day, to search for lettters: And has a gun ready charged to kill pidgeons, for fear they should be Carryers: He swounds at the sight of a post, or any thing that runs of errands.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: This difficulty makes me need thy help. I know thee expert in all the tricks of women; art read in their winks and nods, canst tell how to answer with a shrug or sigh, knowst how to wheadle Chamber Maids, and make love to old nurses. Prethee be serious and advise me.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Now I see thou art in earnest, I can, and will Leandro.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: But how dear Pisauro?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Why thus: old Camillo, Father to thy Ismena, has a son lately return'd from England, whither he went with our Embassador.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: This way I can foresee no hopes.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p:
Yes very much. You knew him humorsome, and conceited before his voyage; but this has added to him all the fopperies of that Nation, which they borrow from the French: so that he's the strangest piece of Fantastickness
that can make droll for a play: in short he is a meer singing switching Fopp.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Still you amaze me.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Suffer me. Amongst the rest of the English customes 'tis one, and faith almost the only one that pleases me, to allow all possible freedom to their women. This he resolves to bring up in Venice, and will in spight of his father, begin with his own sisters. There is a Royal society of us, call'd the Reformers. Dost thou yet understand me?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Yes, this sounds like something.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: We'l admit thee into the number, and then shift for thy self. I must leave you, and to the business that concerns my life (as I was telling you) my little Merchant adventures, Oh! 'tis the kindest thing, so like matrimony, and yet no trouble. Now we talk of reforming, could you all thrive like me, and leave off the damn'd trade of keeping wenches, and let them keep you, 'twould be a happy world.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: But I'me for neither, I'me for the honest way of marrying.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, but that somebody should like that dull trade: for if there were no wives, there would be no husbands to rob to maintain us younger Brothers.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: You still keep your old humor; but why no better drest man?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: I'le tell you; I serve her, as the wenches used to serve me; always pretend to want something: thou shalt see me as glorious as the day at our next meeting.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Stay, who are these?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Antonio and Pedro, two of the society: I'le admit you presently.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Thou'rt a rare rogue: How the Divel could'st thou find Rhetorick enough to wheadle him to this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
He did it himself Sir. And tells me in England, 'tis thought honorable to bring their sisters acquainted, as they call it, I believe some fashionable name for Pimping. 'Tis ordinary there to do it for a kins woman, and that may save a portion.
Heaven send them good faces, and they never need work for their livings. Oh 'tis.—

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Save you Gallants, how does the Society go forward?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: With full sail, Pisauro.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Shall I beg admission for my friend here?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Leandro! The only man we wished; but he must be sworn according to form.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Your Servant Gentlemen, I shall willingly pass any ceremony.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: They are easie, only an oath or two to swallow, and they are gilded.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lay your hand upon the book. 'Tis Ovid de arte amandi, and begin. You shall swear, to the uttermost of your power to reform Venice according to the Pattern of Enland in manners and discipline; and that you will, without respect of persons, endeavour the extirpation of Tyranny, that is, the government of Husbands and Fathers, by Sisters, Aunts, Nurses, and all other officers depending upon that Usurpation. And that you will with the same sincerity root out the spreading errors of Vizards, Masques, Veyles, Padlocks, both for the restoring of lost pleasures to your self, and the freedom of the distressed Ladys.
So help you Cupid.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So, now you are a sworn Brother, we need keep nothing secret.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Where's our Grand-master Pacheco?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I left him with his Tutor, the English man, contriving which way to get his Sisters out of Prison.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: That's the English man, I warrant, that pretends so much to Poetry and breeding; and censures all the old Authors, with as much Authority as if he had been their School-master.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: The same; if he gets but the upper end of a Table at an Ordinary, you shall have him run them over as fast, as a Dutch-man tells money.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Sometimes he pretends to Plays too, and then he damns French, Spanish, and Italian in a wind, yet steals out
of the very worst of them. He would be thought to have a little kindness for an Author or two of his own Nation, but will be sure to ruin their reputation too, with some exception or other, before he leaves them.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Does he ever write himself?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, Yes; but as all your profest Criticks do, damnably ill: To tell you the truth (for I have made it my business to understand him) the fellow has wit, but broke with driving a trade too big for his stock; and when Pacheco took him in, all he had to subsist on, was confidence, and the favour of two or three fopps.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Faith he's bravely fitted with a Master.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis very pleasant to hear him talk of the advantages of this Reformation, his Lectures of Repartes, Converse, Regales, and an hundred more unintelligible fopperies.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: To end, he has order'd us to expect him at the old place, where we shall hear the Result of all.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: There you may expect me then an hour hence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But how shall we find a Mistress for Pacheco?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: — Why faith I have a wench I grow something weary of, he shall have her.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: No, that's too cruel.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What think you of my boy finely drest? The rogue has a smooth face, and sings well.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Nor that neither. I have a Cozen witty and handsome, whose Fathers fortunes were ruin'd in our last wars at Candy: what if we set her up? she may teach him wit.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: As you can agree. But prithee, now you talk of singing, let Leandro hear the song you made upon the Reformation.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sing boy.

lg.l: Beauty no longer shall suffer Eclipse,
The power of those eyes, or use of those lips
Nor shall husband or Father repine.
We'el banish the stratagems us'd by the State
To keep the poor women in aw,
Henceforth they themselves, shall rule their own fate
And desire shall be to them a law.
Where in private we'el teach them the Mysteries of Love,
Till we the fond Scruple of honor remove,
And the end of our passion discover.
For each may be eas'd by her Lover.
Away with all things that sound like to Laws,
Let the Formalists prate, the good old cause

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: 'Tis a brisk design, and must needs take among the Ladies: but are the so free in England as you pretend?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Freer than you can think Sir. 'Tis mortal sin not to know what's what at fifteen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fifteen! They have lost time at that age; a Maiden-head at thirteen is as great a rarity in the country as a wolf; now and then in some village there may be some ugly Monster, that holds out longer upon force, but—

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: In earnest Leandro, the soberest women there, have more freedom of discourse and company, than we give to a stale Bawd, or an old Midwife at a Christening: And yet the men so free from jealousie, that you may as soon perswade one of us to leave whoring, as them to believe their own eyes.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nay, they are so contrary to us, that a Vizard Masque is a certain sign of a free booter, and nothing makes them cover their faces but impudence.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: This must needs be the fortunate Island, people talk so much off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now after all this, make it a matter of conscience: consider the necessity of this Reformation, and how damnably we have been wheadled by these veiles of ours. After half a years attendance, and courting of some delicate shape, that would tempt a Hermit in the midst of snow, to lose all our expectation and compliment, and when we see the Divels face, be forced to fly, and cross our selves for fear of blasting.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: 'Tis intolerable. I tell you I resolve to spare no body, a Vizard sha'n't pass though it be following her Mother to the grave: nor any face be hid by a veil, though the woman be to do penance in a Church: The truth on't is, Gentlemen, there must be no mean, rank rebellion or nothing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: At that I'me with you, and I know not but this may make us as famous, as inventing a new Religion.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: There's no question. Thou art well read, 'tis but finding half a dozen places in our modern Reformers, to back us, and the business is done.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: This design has so tickled me, that I have forgot my assignation. Leandro I leave you to be introduced by these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We'l all go.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: My way lies here, I'le be with you presently.

sp.l: Let your politick nodles debate
So our women be free,
'Tis nothing to him, to thee, or to me
Who governs the Church or the State.

div.stage:
Exeunt. Ant. Ped. Leandro.
as Pisauro is going out at the other door.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: So my adventures begin already: though two to one be odds, I must board them; Heaven send they don't prove Fire-ships

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Tis he.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Nay faith Madam, no passing this way without a small Patley, and a kind look or two.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Sure you'r some stranger you'r so rude, do you know you are in Venice, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Yes Madam, but I perceive you don't know the most considerable news of the place. How the Divel do you two come into these Vizards that have been out of fashion these six hours?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What Sir? and the men are to wear them to cover bad faces, as the women did to save good ones?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Well said Spitfire, come, unmasque for fear I call yours in question; for were you fair, you would be proud too, and we must hire you to keep it on.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Like enough Sir, were the prize worth taking, but what shall I get by conquering you? You look as if you had nothing about you, but a Surgeons bill, and it may be a Taylours, which must be worn out with carrying in your pocket too, if it came home with your cloaths.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: As I live she guesses all my treasure within a Ducatoon: Oh for some succor to relieve the forlorn hope. Aside. Nay if you once turn wit, I'le swear you'r ugly; and now I look again I see your wall eyes, and guess the length of your nose by the shape of your Masque. Faith Madam, the men are beholden to you, that you take such care not to fright them.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Without you repent you shall pine for this, though it be spoke at random.

sp.speaker: Lelia.
sp.p: This is the strangest beggar I ever heard Madam; but you use to be charitable, give him something to put him into repair, the Gentlemen has been in a Storm.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p:
Do you begin to open too, you pispot-emptier, you
must be such by the old lace shoes, and respect you have to follow the fashion at a distance.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Marry come up! one had better be out of the fashion, than out at the elbows.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Methinks one of your complexion might light upon some wife, or easy fool that would buy her pleasures at the price of perriwigs, or a new suit, you have had ill fortune Sir. Prithee Lelia help me to abuse him.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Worse and worse she knows me too: yet refuse me, if (except this minute to Leandro) I ever told it so much as to my Confessor, but most of your women are witches.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Or what do you think of a Gentleman Usher? you have a good fashionable face; and your Lady will see to bring your legs to a fit size.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No, No; I tell you he scorns any thing of Service. The Ladies doat on him, 'tis ten to one, but that hee's just now sent for, you see hee's drest for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Pox on you both, for I have nothing left to say but curses, and they shall be home: may you be both Padlock'd, chayn'd together, and turn'd upon a Common; or which is yet worse, may you always gape for meat, and it be death for any man to feed you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay if you be so good at that, I'le have one for you too; may you have nothing to maintain you, but the favor of some woman, and she grow weary and discard you.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, that bites, I'de give all the world to see this Divel, and will before I go.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay, never take the pains to strive.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: How! Juliana! Could you curse with so much cruelty, when you knew me too?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Don't you deserve it? how do you like my wall-eyes now?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Now you're cruel: Good faith I did not know thee, I was just coming.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I have waited above this two hours, but you men when you once get a hank upon our affections, think you may do any thing.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: By this you sha'n't be angry. I have the pleasan'st story to tell you; come be pleased Lelia shall engage for me.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Yes I have cause, you did not abuse me?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Peace, I'le stop thy mouth with a husband Girle.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Say you so? I have done.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Well I'le try you once again, but if ever— I'le only go round and meet you, you have the key of the back door.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: What fool will trust himself to wind and waves?
When thus he reaps the fruit and trouble saves?
A Husband's factor for his wifes Gallant,
And till he break, the other nere can want.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: That was something nigh it, but methinks I ha'n't the right fling yet. I'le try agen.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I here you nickt it. Now for your Virtuoso's Looking glass.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.stage: Pulls out a piece of polisht mettal.)

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Right Sir, that expresses your design of promoting new experiments. You must observe it in every thing not so much as a tooth-picker, but must have something extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Would not this shew genteel and modish in a Play-house?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: This and the managing your comb will make you pass for a Critick in the fashion. The next thing you may practice is some few books, and then you are a wit too.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: That's the only thing I aim at; on good Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: When you come to a new Play, and know the Author is no fighter, and you may venture to abuse him; first sit grave and unconcern'd, and be sure to cast an eye upon some fam'd wit of the town, and take him for your pattern.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: But how if there be none there Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p:
Why then if any thing takes in general you may venture
to smile a little: if only amongst some few, and you imagine it not good, cast a scornful look about you, as if you pittied their ignorance. Above all things commend nothing without some exception. These few rules well observ'd, you'l be a standard of carriage unto others.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Nay, they almost take me for a wit already, I know all the Poets Christen names; and call Tom and Jack with as much confidence, as if I had been their God-father.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: That's well: There's very much in that. You may take occasion to give them the familiar shrug, talk aloud, and swear, Tom the humour in thy last Prologue was high and new. Pox on thee for a rogue, thoul't grow famous. A whisper now and then, with a great laugh after it does well.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Did not you talk something of a shrug? You promis'd to teach me the way of accosting people, that's the word I think in England.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Yes, mark▪ First take notice of no body in bad cloaths, or poor, though it should be your own Father come out of the country for to see you: or if you must needs speak to him, withdraw, and after half a score words return, and tell the company that a Tenant wants dispatch, or a dependant on the family; and you'l be with them presently.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: I sha'n't forget this, 'tis so natural to me ever since I have been in England. I can't tell what to say to any one that wants a white wig, and a new suit.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: When you're nigh a person of honour, and one you think it a credit to be acquainted with, be sure to turn and smile, though it be a secret hee's whispering to another, and you don't hear a word. This makes you be thought familiar, and a favorite at Court

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: That's excellent, faith Tutor I'le remember I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p:
As for your Equals, your shrug, or shaking of the head, as if you had been at a debauch the night before, is creditable and modish. As to practice: Mounsieur Pacheco? shrugs. Come, how is't? shrugs What at some deep engagement
with the Ladies last night, or a tavern on my life. shrugs.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: That's right, and confirms him, that you drink and wench, things of more credit, as the world goes, than a Knight-hood, or the command of a Regiment.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Incomparable Tutor! but no more, for fear I forget: besides I fear they stay for us; and I would not hinder the Reformation, to be great Duke.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: In England, where each Writer shares the stakes,
The gains are small, and one the other breaks.
But here alone without controul I rule,
His trade can't fail that's Tutor to a fool.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: I Tell you truth Sir.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Pisauro? the thing it self does not so much perplex me, as that I'me over-reacht; and yet it cannot be; she's all fondness.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: What greater ground can you propose for your suspicion? Consider Sir, had you the same design what other way is left to hide it? But I have done the office of a friend believed or not.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: This argument has convinced me, and since thou art so much my Friend, I'le tell you, I have the same design, and love a Mistress more than twenty Wives, and by this very means conceal it from her. But People that pretend themselves to cunning, seldom see through others. Dost think he's there now?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I'me sure he was Sir within this half hour I see him enter.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Then I will surprize them. I know she can't expect me yet a day or two. I'le only dispatch an houres business Gives him gold. and be with them. Pray accept of this acknowledgment, you're far from home and trust me 'tis a real kindness. For had I found it out my self I know not what a sudden heat might drive me to. A little time to pawse will make me unconcern'd.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: If this project chance to fail, within a day or two I'le find out one that shall be certain.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Till my one eyes convince me I'le be still the same. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir. Thus far things go well, and here's a good reward. But let me think. This Gallant keeps his Mistriss too. That shall to Juliana. And since they are so much for Reformation I'le show them one more of our Country tricks. The taking fees on both sides.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: THis England must be a blessed place my Brother talks so much of it.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Would I were there; that I might be acquainted with these men, I have such a tickling runs through me when I see them.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: And there it is commoner for them to go to a treat, than for us to go to Church; never a day but this Lords or that Knights Coach waits on you and hurrys you to a Play, thence into the Park, then there's such perpetual Masquerades and Balls, that 'tis Carnival all the year.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: And here if we have a little liberty before Lent we are sure to pine for't, so that the whole year scarce recruits us again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: They have no such thing there: they account it almost sin not to eat flesh when 'tis forbidden by the Church.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: That's a life worth something, I wonder why these old men live, sure there they all dy when they're young, or else the women never knew their Fathers, for my part I wish I had never known mine: I'me sure he's grievous troublesome.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Fie Ismena consider he is your Father.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Fie me no fies, Mariana, I wonder who disturbs his telling of money, or any thing he has a mind to: does he think because he had the pleasure to get us, we are bound to be his Slaves? if he had not been my Father 'tis odds but somebody else would, I've heard them say my Mother was a handsome woman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Peace for shame and be content a while, you know what my Brother promised us to day.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: I wish he would make his words good and bring them once. But I have a strong fancy we shall quarrel, for I have had a mind to every man I have seen yet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I wish it were come to that once, for I am grievous weary of working these vertuous Stories of constant wives.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Constant! thine I think's Penelope an old withered witch that was forced to spin ten years to earn money to pay her drudges with; and when she had wearied them all out, sent to seek her Husband; mine's Lucretia, it may be she was vertuous but it would never grieve one to kill ones self, so one was well ravished first.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Now thou art stark mad.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Phu! we may say any thing amongst our selves, if we did not talk merrily how should we be able to live?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Heark, I hear my Father, Heaven send him in a better humor than when he last left us.

sp.speaker: Is
sp.p: He'd best look to himself, for such another Scold would cut off two or three years at least.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: So, this I like, if I ever catch you abroad again without my leave, do you hear I'le have your legs tyed together.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: We may sometimes go to Church Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No, I'de rather have thee stay at home and be damn'd; I wonder what 'tis you do at Church? make mouths at some young fellow, who talks to you all the while on his beads. Come come, I know all your tricks and will have you stay at home; nor shall any come to see you, no not your Brother to tell you Stories of his England voyage: curse on the Nation.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Not my Brother Sir? this is too severe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No not your Brother Minks; you're like to come to good when you'l be instructing of your Father. Here Nurse take the Keys, and give no more liberty than the two next rooms afford without my order.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: I warrant you Sir, I'le keep them close.
Now Mrs. Ismena I shall be even with you for all your frumps.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Nay as long as you are with us we shall want no sport, come Sister help me to shake her to pieces.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: Will you murder me? Oh!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The other shake does it, I heard her bones rattle.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: Oh I am dead.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You keep them close you old toadstool! thou art too ugly to be a Bawd.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: She had been a Witch Sister, but that the Divel loathed to suck her.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: When you are once in your pound I'le make you fast for this, you sha'n't so much as see a man this twelve-moneth, nay, I'le have your hands tied behind you, that you may not scratch where it itches.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: That would be hard indeed Sister.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Leave your threats, or you know your old punishment: or what do you think of tossing her in a blanquet? she's so old and dry she must be light.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p:
Excellent! if we had her in the Garden on a windy day 'twould be a sure riddance; But now I think on't Sister
we'l get some packthread and fly her as the boyes do a paper kite with a Candle and Lanthorn at her tayl. She'l make a rare Comet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis the best use of her, she's like the picture of one of the Sibylls above in the Dining room, and this is the way to make her prophecy.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: Well Mrs. Percks this goes to your Father, with some improvement of my own.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If you dare Keeks, we'l in and study a revenge.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Farewell Rattle, and be sure to keep us close.

div.stage: The old woman locks them in.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: So, if you will prate, Magpies, it shall be in a Cage. These Gimcracks if they once come towards fifteen are so gamesome, there's no riding them without a curb, nay then 'tis ten to one but that they fling the first Adventurer out of the Saddle too. The Divel's in them I think, I'me sure in my young days. But I'de as good stop I shall be tempted to lie else. The truth is I hate all young women that are fair and there's reason for't; if we old ones get a good look once a twelvemonth, be sure the next young one that passes by robs us.

div.stage: Enter Pacheco, Pedro, Antonio, Leandro, and Tutor.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, the old man's safe, enter, and think your selves in England: there we run about till we find the Ladies Chambers, ransack every thing, and are never chid except it be for not staying longer. What say you, Tutor?

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: He tells you truth Gallants, we help to dress and undress faith almost any thing; yet all the while as Vertuous as two Nuns. More, you'l find there is no other way but liberty to make us so.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I'me glad to hear the way to Vertue is so easy Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.p: I alwayes thought it, there's none but a company of ill-natur'd morose people that would have it hard can think it otherwise.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Can any one believe that such a glorious thing as woman is, was made to be conceal'd?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, ' tmust be cursed Heresie, I had rather they should put out the Sun by half.

sp.speaker: Pache.
sp.p: That's because you love their company in the dark. Was not that good, Tutor?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Hey day! who have we here? I have heard of Guardian Angels, but never thought that Divels were so employed before.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: You know the fashion Sir of your own Country. This is the sweet-meat keeper, the preserver of Maiden heads that shall for a Ducat corrupt youth, and teach them more bawdy in a week than half a dozen years practice; yet is trusted with as much beauty as is able to make the great Turks Empire run mad, merely for being old and ill natur'd. In short Sir here our Reformation must begin.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come at her then.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: What do you mean Gentlemen? I'me onely a poor old Servant to the house.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Thy being old is enough to make us hate thee.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Come where are my Sisters? give me the keys.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: No such matter, my Master charged me but just now to the contrary, and I will be true.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Give me them you Witch or—

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: I'le cry out, will you force me?

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: Have you got them?

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Yes, Yes.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: But how shall we stop her mouth? an old womans tongue is harder to lay than ten Divels.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Let me alone with her, I go always prepared to stop these noises.

div.stage: Ant. Gags and binds her and throws her out.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: There lie thee there, and dare but so much as think mischief, and do you hear I'le pull out the two stumps that are left.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Here Gallants take these keys. Now you may enter and catch who catch can a la mode d' Angleterre, I disturb nobody not I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A kind Brother this! Aside it shall go hard but I will have a Sister for you Sir.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: My jealousie makes it but too true I am in love, and that with such respect that 'tis impossible to benefit by this freedom.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Courage Sir, I perceive you are one of the cold contemplative lovers that follow a Mistriss at a distance, and think your self happy if you purchase one gracious nod, with ten thousand cringes. In for shame.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: If you'l carry me to one of your Ladies, I'le soon teach you better courtship. Or if you'l stay here. You shall see me practise.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I shall be glad to learn Sir.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Come Tutor show me the way of address to a Lady.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: Did you never see the Gallants in the Antechamber, how they prepare themselves before entrance?

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Yes I warrant, what was I in England so long for else? but will that do?

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: The very same.

div.stage: Sets his wig and shirt and tricks himself.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Then thus.
How do you like this Sir?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Oh Sir much beyond any thing I ever saw. I must have patience with this fool for his Sisters sake.

sp.speaker: Tutor▪
sp.p: Then Sir we don't go your formal old way of making legs, as if we had some Deity to worship. But knowing they are flesh and blood as well as we approach briskly.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Begin with an oath or two. I think it is not much matter whether it be to the purpose or not Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: Not at all Sir, they'l excuse all that follows for the sake of that.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: These are great secrets, you improve me Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Nay Sir, if we carry on our Reformation, the whole state will stand engaged to us, but great designs seldom prosper at the first.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: The more's our ignorance, but pray Sir in. If there be such a toy as a Masque or Fan to play with, or you can find any thing new about her to commend 'tis modish, and the most gentile subject for discourse.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: If you name two or three Ladies of quality familiarly, it sounds well and brings you in esteem. But most of all if you can learn who she hates (for women have always little quarrels amongst themselves) and can pick up a story to their disadvantage, you render your self beyond exception acceptable.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: I do it alwayes, but nothing pleases them so much as a little sprinkling of bawdy Tutor. Only the Divels in't, the rogues perpetually out-do me at it.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: No wonder Sir, they practise daily, and no three women that are acquaintance but make a Bawdy language for their own use.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: I wish you had a Sister Sir, or so, that you might see me practise or'e these lectures,

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: 'Tis my misfortune Sir.

sp.speaker: Pache.
sp.p: But suppose for once that you were my Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Pacheco.
sp.p: Thus I come up.
sp.stage: Sings a piece of a Tune.
sp.p: And how? damn me Madam all a mort?

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: Incomparably well!

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Must I swear too?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: No Sir by no means, if the women once get that (as there is a faction amongst them that endeavour it) they rob us of half our discourse. But say what you will I have news from the last Ball, or of some new Beauty kept by such a one. Or a new Play to find fault with or commend according as I hear who made it.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: And when you once get them into the discourse of Plays they'l run on themselves. Praise such an Actor for this part, a second for another, a third for a comely man, a fourth for dancing well.

sp.speaker: Pache.
sp.p: Nay Sir, if you meet with a woman that does not find you discourse on this subject, conclude her some Jilt that never had the good luck to be pickt up there, or some poor whore that can't purchase a seat.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: But what do you do all the time?

sp.speaker: Pache.
sp.p:
Comb my Wig by her glass and twenty other
gentile tricks. But you must have time to learn, I my self am beholden to travel, and this good man my Tutor here.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I despair of e're attaining such perfections.

sp.speaker: Pache.
sp.p: Industry may do much, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.p: So, here they come; does not this look better than making legs to a belcony and blowing kisses up and down.

sp.speaker: Pache.
sp.p: This is right. Blest Reformation!

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I find this English custom will not down with me, I'me too much an Italian not to be jealous of the thing I love.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: You may think us rude for to be thus familiar; but a Fathers strictness, and my Brothers good lessons have instructed us.

sp.speaker: Pedro.
sp.p: It's nothing Madam but what becomes all People that are Vertuous; 'tis only such as drive a trade, and gain by seeming nice that should be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Phy Sister, you sin against our Covenant to go about t' excuse your self; for my part I think we need none, I'me sure our souls are free as any mans: And yet forsooth our bodies must be confin'd, and that by old men and women too, people by their very natures made unfit for liberty.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Brave Virago! You shall be our Captain Madam in this holy war.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: She's my own Sister Sir, you see that.
This is a modest Gentleman of the Reformation, pray bid him welcome. I and my Tutor have been reading to him and we have hopes of his improvement.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your friend must challenge welcome here, Brother.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: The being a Reformer gives it him in's own right.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: You heap your honors too fast on me Ladies, and the obligation is too far above my merit.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: There's stuff indeed. Can't you serve her as I told you I would one of your Sisters? But the first fault shall be pardon'd.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Still worse it gnaws here.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fie Brother, the Gentleman speaks well.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Yes if he would hold up his head a little, and not begin with such a long word as obligation.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I have lost all patience.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Mark Sir, you should cringe thus, speak two or three half sentences, as, I vow Madam, take me but, and all that. And then come up boldly.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: 'Tis well you are her Brother. I find
sp.l: I must contrive my ends some other way,
And when she's once a wife she shall obey.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: You may end your Lecture, the Gentleman's gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Gone! then let him live in ignorance.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: If you're always thus exact brother, we shall ne're increase our Company.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You must pardon him, he was always humorsome.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: 'Tis strange, when People have such opportunities and wont improve themselves.
Art thou come dear Rogue? let me kiss the. Here Sisters, share him, this is my second that I told you of. If we meet with any opposition in our great affair.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: But that we meet on the design of freedom Ladies, I might easily have been thought rude to have intruded thus.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Nothing but your free humor can make you welcome here.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: 'T would be happiness to purchase it at any rate, but this doubles the favour Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Fie Sir, this sounds too like a Compliment. We should be loth to lose the good opinion we have of you.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Have done for shame or I shall read you one of your friend Leandros Lectures.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Pray what have you done to make him leave your Company?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Trust me nothing but mirth, but Lovers are humorsome.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Sir, no more.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Come Gallants now we're met, what think you of a Dance?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: We want Musick and Ladies.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Not so fast good Sir, here's two to four of you, in England 'tis common to go halfes, and the women never complain neither. No, no. The Musick, is the thing. Oh Tutor for the four and twenty English Violins now. You'd think your selves in Heaven, Gentlemen, at a new Play. There we stand up with our Mistresses in our hands, keep time and court them to the humor of the aire, have one particular sort of strain to gripe at, another for a languishing look. We Italians find fault with your Tramontanes, but we are dull we are dull to them.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Pray let's defer that for our next meeting; if these Ladies will but honor me to be my guests, I'le take care these wants shall be supplied.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: I'le engage for them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now we have begun this way of freedom we should be uncivil to deny you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: But how shall we get loose?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: That shall be provided for before we part. It is but just the first time be spent in the publick service.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Some Chairs there.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Well proposed, and that the rules of Reformation be decreed by joint consent.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: At least that every one should undertake besides the Generall work, some one particular for to advance the Reformation.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Let's to the consultation then.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: First I propose Pacheco be voted perpetual Chair-man to the Society; as one of whose faithfulness and zeale we've had sufficient proof.
All. Agreed.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: W' accept the honor Gentlemen, and hope we may deserve it by our future diligence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come Ladies will it please you sit.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Do you use t' admit of women to your privy counsel?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Yes Madam they still have had the casting vote in every Reformation.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay then wee'l never lose our Priviledge.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: First I declare my Tutor secretary.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: You've made a happy choice.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Next, as a thing that's very much conducing to the Reformation, I undertake to regulate and be the pattern of all fashions in the town. To further which my Secretary shall dispatch and keep a correspondence with our beloved pattern England.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Why not with France? they borrow all from thence.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: True Sir, and I have known some scores of Gallants that sail thither twice or thrice a year on that design. And are expected by the rest with as much earnestness as the East- India fleet by those that make the greatest venture.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Yes Tutor, but they make some new additions of their own; as your fring'd glove, curle of the wig, or cut of the belt, which strikes me strangely. Besides, they much improve the gate and ceremony. And out-do the French in their own way cringe and wadle.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: These are Arguments beyond objection. I undertake t'invent a Language for the company, I mean some twenty words or more of constant use. Or sense or not, all's one so long as fashionable.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Good, and the true Genteel English way of wit. You shall have a Gallant pay his devoirs, testifie his amours, and make his assignations some twenty times a day.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: To this I'le add as many stories too. To which we must refer all our discourse. This serves instead of whispering.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Oh much better; but then the Ladies must engage to seem to understand and laugh at all you say.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's easy, for we always do pretend to know more than we do.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: 'Tis but as all that would be thought great wits do, Sister.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: I have a project now on foot which will advance the Reformation, but beg I may once more try the experiment before I do reveal't.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: It's granted. What say you Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why I will undertake for to reform all the old men in Venice to the English way. Expect within a week to see them in their Wigs and with their chins new shav'd, like boys of fifteen. Nay more, I do intend for to begin with old Camillo too himself.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: 'Tis a bold project, succeed or not.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: For my part I'le stick to my old way and write you Plays and Songs. I know they never fail. I'le undertake the last new Play or two I writ made the young Ladies more free, and brought more kind couples together, than all the old women or Pages in the Country.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Probatum est. I've reap'd the benefit of that my self. What say the Ladies now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: We can only promise for to follow your instructions, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: And that we do in every thing: with a little more experience we may venture to undertake some project of our selves.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Bravely resolved Ladies. No cause can fail that's backt by two such Champions.

sp.speaker: Tut
sp.p: Will you give me leave to give you some advice.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Leave? you're Tutor to the Society.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Then first—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Heark what noise is that, for Heaven sake look out. Oh we're undone Sister.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: 'Twill be in good company then.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: 'Tis Antonio's Boy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is he coming?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Away with these things there quickly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He is not very near yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Go out and give us more notice.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Ladies, if you follow my advice you may have freedom without fear.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: We'l follow any thing to purchase that.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p:
Here onely take this Powder, and when your Father
calls for wine mingle it with this, within an hour it will make him sleep, and you free.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But is there no danger Sir?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: A child may take it Madam.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: He's just here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then we have no time for complement.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: You remember your promise Ladies. Come Pacheco you shall go along with me, it shall be hard but I will have a Mistriss for you. This does but set thy teeth on edge.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: This way, this way, by the back door.

div.stage: Mariana and Ismena pull out their works.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray Sister let's be very dutiful for fear he should mistrust.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I warrant you; do you think I am to learn to counterfeit at fifteen?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Now I'me pleased, be still thus dutiful, and you shall find me an Indulgent Father. I am contriving something unto your advantage Mariana, you shall hear it shortly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I shall wait your commands Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: That was well said, and for you too Ismena.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: If it pleases you Sir I must needs be satisfied, I was always taught to be dutiful.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Thou hast thy Mothers soul. I am o'rejoy'd to find thee thus. Where's the Nurse?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I forgot to tell you Sir, as soon as you went out, she was taken with a most violent raving fit. And talkt and rayled so loud she quite frighted us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then on the sudden was struck dumb. And has not spoke one word since.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Poor woman. I'le go see her.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: No, pray Sir she's now fast and you'l disturb her.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Well thought on. 'tis only rest that must compose her. But hark what noise is that! Again!

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: 'Tis the Nurse, for Heaven sake Sister run and ungag her we're undone else, and leave me to my Father.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: What's the house hanted at this time of day?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: 'Tis only the poor Nurse Sir that wakes in her distracted fit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good dear, dear Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: Not I, it shall out.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'le give you my best Peticoat, good Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: Not all the world shall hire me. Oh Sir!

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Pray Sister help me to hold her. Her fit increases, Lord how her eyes rowl! Aside Sweet Nurse I'le give thee any thing.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Oh Master! Such a noise, such singing, nay pray Heaven it were no worse, for they were roaring Boys.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: She raves indeed, what dost mean Nurse?

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: I mean here Sir, with your daughter some five or six of them.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Poor old creature, how strong her fancy is? let's bind her Sir, they say that that will hinder it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Here's no body but I and you and my two daughters.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: But there was Sir. Heaven grant you have no grand-children in store, for I begin to doubt them.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Just thus she talkt before she slept, a little Opium would do well to settle her. (good Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: You think to carry it off, but now my Gag's out it shall be known. And how you contrived.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I found them here at work alone.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: I'me apt to think they're work was done before you came Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Pray Ismena, what does she mean by this?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Heaven knows, some sad distraction Sir, I doubt she has been wicked in her youth.

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: Come, Come I doubt you are. I see old Age and Service cannot be believed.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Mark Sister, now she's in her crying fit too. I'le call for help and put her to bed.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here's a Gentleman without that calls himself Leandro, Sir, has business with you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I come, carry out the Nurse and let the Maids look after her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I think they had best bind her. Pray Heaven she do no mischief.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Her teeth are all out, she can't bite.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now what do you think on't Nurse?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: I think you're all possest, for to abuse me thus. All that vexes me, I ne're deserv'd it at my Masters hands. But I will be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: This is beyond expectation. Pray Heaven our next frolick succeed as well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'me strangely afraid of this Leandro.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: That's the Melancholy man that was with us, is it not?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The same; if he betray us we're undone yet.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Ne're fear wench, this powder will be one shift more.
sp.l: And whether Fortune smiles or knits her brow,
We can't be worse than slaves, and so we're now.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I thought my self engaged besides the particular love I bear your daughter, by my tie to honor to declare this truth.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis very strange.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: The Nurse can justifie it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Why, she's distracted Sir.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: She might well seem so, abused as she has been.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come in with me and wee'l examine further, and if it does prove true, I stand obliged.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: If not, then take your own revenge.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
'Twas well we had this notice, we had been surprized else. What unlucky business brings him back? Now must I be
kist and hugg'd by one I hate. Phaugh. He said Lysander told it him himself, did he not?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Very well, the more he doats on's Mis, the more time shall I have with my Gallant, and if he does chance to find me out I have something to cry quit with. In the mean time I'le seem as fond as ever, lest he should suspect me.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Heark Madam, I think I hear him coming.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis he.
Next I will have you work the dismal story of poor Ariadnes love, and how the cruel Theseus left her, 'twas unkindly done Lelia: But men are not so fond as we.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Pox of your counterfeit pipe, he has been here but fled.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Ar't ' come dearest? now thou'rt kind indeed, a suddain joy o'rewhelming me. I was just talking of the cruelties of men, and pittying our poor sex. But I had never yet a cause to doubt of thee. Ten thousand welcomes. I have had such fears.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Lest I should come home too soon Aside. Thou art so fond, I must believe thee, I am o'rejoy'd to find thee in this health. Trust me I've scarcely slept since last we parted.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No, you had one that kept you waking Aside Poor Dear I pitty thee; you wanted me to sing and kiss thee to thy rest.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Truth is, no Opium causes sleep so much as such a bedfellow.— I hate Aside.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay I my self have had the strangest dreams too.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I hope they were all pleasant ones.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: They were all of you, you night and day dispose my thoughts. One time methoughts you loved another woman more than me, that troubled me a little, as it would any wife that loves so well as I do. But I believe there are but few.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p:
Heaven forbid there should. Aside That was thy
too much fondness, thou can'st not have those thoughts awake.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: No dearest joy, 'twas only in a dream.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: That's nothing, for I had such a one of you, but when I wak'd I chid my self.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay, then we're even, and must pardon one another.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: There's reason for't, for you are both sinners.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I am so far from a mistrust, that I dare swear thou art as innocent, as I my self.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I dare pawn my innocence for thee too.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: And if you ne're redeem't 'tis no great loss.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But why should we talk thus? it looks too like mistrust. Believe me t'was with me an Age till your return.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: The very last hour before mine, seemed months to me too. I would fain have taken you napping.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Poor rogue, you're thin since last I saw you, you shall not go agen.

sp.speaker: Lelia.
sp.p: A Mistriss and a Wife's enough to mak any body look so.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Nay dearest but I must, and leave thee for a week or two, an hour is the longest of my stay.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And of my life. You will kill me.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: It shall be with kindness then.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A week! I know thou'rt not in earnest but wilt deceive me thus agen, come prithee do, these surprizes make thy coming ten times pleasanter.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: That was well nickt, to make sure work.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: 'Tis too certain, Juliana, that's the least; nay, never cry for't. But let's enjoy that little time we have, come prithee leave.
sp.l: They say that married peoples Loves decay,
But mine still grows

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And mine,— another way.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: COme hang't, why all this mincing? can you imagine I'me so dull as not to see through it? Ten to one I know the cause of your Mumps; as much, I find the rise of your sullenness. In short Pedro you have a months mind to measure lengths with Madam Mariana, and you Antonio have as much to a day to try how things will fit with brisk Ismena.
