Come, confess, confess; I see plainly by your solemn pace and grave contriving looks, you have been running over all the stories in Romances to accomplish your designs.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I must declare that I have no aversion to the freedom of her humour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I have seen some faces and conditions which I have liked much worse. But—

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Pox on you both! don't you think this sounds very prettily to one that has been an Adventurer, in this trade of love? You must give me leave to know that your no aversion is the height of desire, and your liking much worse is the same with nothing half so well. But this silly love still thinks, because he's blind himself, no body else must see.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nay, Pray Pisauro, for charity invent some other name, though it should prove the self same thing, for this is scandalous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, No, 'tis so, I plainly see all men have a certain time allowed to play the fool, and love in, and this is mine.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: This is honest and a friendly part. But why the Divel don't you tell them so? you see we're more put to't to lay the jealousie of old Camillo, than we should be to raise a Ghost, to gain an houres leisure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I thought I ventured fair considering t'was the first time.

sp.speaker: Pis
sp.p: That's very fine, the first time? is not the Gallant worthy more applause that hits the mark the first shoot, than he that draws a dozen times and ne're comes nigh the spot? I'me sure the Ladies will commend him for his aime.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: But you know the Custom does require Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: As for customes, our Reformation is design'd for to destroy them all. And this first in short Gentlemen, there are but two wayes you can design to be possessours of your hopes: either to perswade them to their fashionable way of love, or be content your selves to marry them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But neither of these, I doubt, will do, Pisauro; 'tis certain they are too wise and vertuous for the first; too brisk and jolly for the second.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Truth is, their briskness makes me fear they are honest.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Could I find them otherwise, I should soon make an end of all my love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith, thought I formerly have had no great opinion of the other, yet I resolve to try it now, and carry on the Reformation too. Venice shall learn from me the freedom due to Wives. What sayest thou, Pedro?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nay, I am too much thy friend to leave thee in the greatest hazard of thy life.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Well agreed. I shall give you opportunity anon, if my design succeeds with old Camillo: though I begin to doubt because the Tutor comes not. By this Pacheco and his Mistriss have chang'd a broad-side or two; I left them nigh engaging.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: There is no danger in the combat I presume.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Faith, not on her side, she has little to lose besides the Vessel, let him board her when he will.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Have you got the Tutors consent yet?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: That I intend to buy with gold and good words, and the money will be well put out to use too; the fool must needs be rich, and the wench I know has wit enough to wheadle him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: But do you think he'le bite home enough to marry?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p:
Yes, I know she'l stand upon her honour, the unknown
value of a womans credit, and twenty such common places they all inherit from their Mothers, and if he once grow hot he will do any thing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Have you heard any news of Leandro?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Yes, but am loth to tell a story so imperfect; the Tutor will tell us all.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Does that Fellow continue his old humour still?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Without the least change, if not improved.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee put him into 't a little.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: You'l repent you, for 'tis intolerable.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No, No, for once we'l venture it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis much that this fellow that has wit, and is company in every thing besides, should thus besot himself.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Let's work a cure and beat him out of this humour.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: If beating would have done he had been well long ere this.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Methinks change of air should work.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: No, nothing, he picks out half a dozen young fools where e're he comes, sticks to them till he has talk'd o're all he has to say, and then changes. st

Here he comes, let's dispatch our business first: Welcome Sir, what news? you look as if you'd had a Play hist, or met with some presumptuous fool that would pretend to understand the rules of Poetry in your company.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: No none of these, but something that concerns you nearer at the present: in short, Leandro has betray'd all, renounced his covenant, and become Reprobate.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith, I expected no better, I knew he must necessarily turn Heretick by this way of living: alas, he drunk nothing but Penitential water and dangerous Coffee, half a dozen such Sneaks would ruin the Republick.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Prithee, what new light or Revelation rules him now?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p:
The old flame of Love, and he goes the old Italian way to work too: makes his addresses to the Father without consulting the woman: Has told of your being there, the Rules of your Reformation; and by this art so wheadled
him that he resolves to marry one of his daughters to him immediately; to which end he's just now gone to fetch a Priest. Yonder has been such a Lecture, what between the old man and the Nurse, that the Poor Ladies have been worried.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Which of the Sisters is't?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Ismena, that's it which vexes me, h'as pickt the flower out of all our conquest.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But he shall hang before he e're shall wear her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No, it must not be; if we let the first rebellion prosper, we betray the weakness of our Government.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: I knew him false before, and therefore promised to assist you in your loves, from hence I do renounce all friendship with him as a Traytor.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou art truly Loyal. Pray let me beg the freedom to contrive his punishment; if I make him not as wretched and ridiculous as his worst of enemies can wish, trust me with no more affairs of State.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: But how shall we escape this danger?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Has be taken the powder yet?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Yes, that's all our hopes. He railed himself so dry that he was forced to call for wine If that works before Leandro comes, we should be freed for the present, the Nurse too has a dose to spoil her talking.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That's well, could we but meet him.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: He must come this way, for he went towards the Arsenal.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then we are safe, let me alone to manage him.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: In the mean time let us divert our selves.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I thought to have met Pacheco here, 'tis certain he must not come nigh home till old Camillo is appeased; nor I neither.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: He's in a safer place practising all his Lectures over to his Mistriss. I have a project now on foot which if you'l promise to advance you shall want no gold; but of that anon.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I shall endeavour to serve you Sir.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Come Sir you are a judge, what opinion have you of the last new Play?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Faith— well for an essay. I guess the Gentlemans but a beginner. I my self—

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Now he's in.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Writ with the same much success at first, 'twas industry and much converse that made me ripe; I tell you Gentlemen, when I first attempted this way I understood no more of Poetry than one of you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: This is strange impudence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing yet.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: There are many pretenders but you see how few succeed; and bating two or three of this nation as Tasso, Ariosto and Guarini, that write indifferently well, the rest must not be named for Poesy: we have some three or four, as Fletcher, Iohnson, Shakespear, Davenant, that have scribled themselves into the bulk of follies and are admired to, but ne're knew the laws of heroick or dramatick poesy, nor faith to write true English neither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis very much, I hope Sir your heroick play goes on.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: As fast as a piece of that exactness can. I'le only leave a pattern to the world for the succeeding ages and have done.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Oh Sir you'l wrong the world.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: No faith Sir I grow weary of applause.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Will you give me leave to ask the way for others to attain to your perfection?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I will not say but that it may be done, but trust me you'l find it hard Gentlemen, and since you are my friends I'le tell you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You will oblige us Sir.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: First I speak of Tragedy, which let the world say what it will and doat on little things, I scrible now and then, as good faith they doe Gentlemen strangely; you shall have them— but I don't love to praise my self. Tragedy I say's my Masterpiece.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Every tthing you do seems so.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, pray forbear Gentlemen— To go on: I take a subject, as suppose the Siege of Candy, or the conquest
of Flanders, and by the way Sir let it alwayes be some war-like action; you can't imagine what a grace a Drum and Trumpet give a Play. Then Sir I take you some three or four or half a dozen Kings, but most commonly two or three serve my turn, not a farthing matter whether they lived within a hundred years of one another, not a farthing Gentlemen, I have tryed it, and let the Play be what it will, the Characters are still the same.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Trust me Sir, this is a secret of your art.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: As Sir you must alwayes have two Ladies in Love with one man, or two men in love with one woman; if you make them the Father and the Son, or two Brothers, or two Friends, 'twill do the better. There you know is opportunity for love and honour and Fighting, and all that.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Very well Sir.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Then Sir you must have a Hero that shall fight with all the world; yes i'gad, and beat them too, and half the gods into the bargain if occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This method must needs take.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: And does Sir. But give me leave and mark it for infallible, in all you write reflect upon religion and the Clergy; you can't imagine how it tickles, you shall have the Gallants get those verses all by heart, and fill their letters with them to their Country friends; believe me this one piece of art has set off many an indifferent Play, and but you are my friends—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You honour us.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Last of all, be sure to raise a dancing singing ghost or two, court the Players for half a dozen new scenes and fine cloaths (for take me if there ben't much in that too) put your story into rime, and kill enough at the end of the Play, and Probatum est your business is done for Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: A'n 't you weary?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No prithee let him run on.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Then as for Comedy, which I was saying my Genius does not lead me to, but that the world may know I can at idle houres when I please out-write them, I do venture at.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: And with success Sir too, believe it.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: And faith Gentlemen I'le tell you, there's your French Nation, Pox on 't a kind of Jack-pudding wit, yet hang me if their Plays be well pick'd, as a scene here and a scene there, it will do it, it will i' faith, I have try'd it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Well Sir proceed.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: But your true English and my way, is to write your Plays with double sence and brisk meaning Songs. Take me, you shall have the Ladies laugh at a little bawdy jest as if they would bepiss themselves, and the young Mounsieurs clap as if they meant to wear their hands out in the service; and if you consider, this is easy and a large subject, especially to one that will be at the charge to keep a wench that understands her trade, you can't imagine what hints and pretty things she will pick up. Now Sir, if you can but maintain two or three of those Characters, no matter what your plot is, your love and honour will do here agen, and 'tis but saving alive and marrying those that you would kill in Tragedy, and you have done.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We give you thanks for these instructions, and shall endeavour to improve Sir.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Nay, I have not done yet, but if you promise secrecy will let you know my great Arcanum.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: 'Tis this, when I have writ a Play, I pick some Lady out of general acquaintance, or favourite at the Court, that would be thought a wit, and send it in pretence for to submit it to her judgment. This she takes for such a favour— and raises her esteem so much— she talks of nothing else but Mr. such a ones new Play, and picks out the best on 't to repeat, so half the town by this means is engag'd to clap before they come.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Besides this, I take some half a dozen youngsters of the town, People that pride themselves in one of my nods or a shaking by the hand at the Coffee-house, and let them have a copy of a Song or two, or promise of the Prologue, which does so much oblige, that I have all the faction of the town that makes a noise on my side.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Trust me Sir these are very great rules.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: And such as never fail, but I am resolv'd to leave, and having made a pattern for the world so long deceiv'd in their opinion of wit and Language.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: For heaven sake pitty us now Pisauro, and perswade him to keep this for his Aside Preface to the next new Play.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Not I, since you have wound him up, may you be deaf with noise.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here comes one that will release us then.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: We must keep him in talk a while.
Leandro here! that's a miracle, where hast thou been for heavens sake? thou might'st have found the North passage to the Indies since I saw thee.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Troth Gentlemen I have found out as difficult a one to as pleasant a place, and am just going to reap the benefit of my adventure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We may all share I hope.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: No, I'me for c'd to monopolise for all the sweets and treasures of the place, if once they're blow'd upon or toucht by more than one, lose all their value and delight.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Are you the first discoverer that you challenge such propriety?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I've reason to think so, for th' accesses were all guarded by a watchful dragon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In plain language Sir.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I'le tell you then because I am in hast; since I left you I have been with old Camillo, drawn up writings, agreed every thing between us, and only want a Priest (which is just going thither) to make Ismena mine; was not my passage shorter than ordinary, Gentlemen, and the Island worth discovery? Pray Gentlemen how does the Reformation go forward?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: But hast thou no remorse, no pricking all this time?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: For what prithee?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p:
Is thy zeal for the solemn covenant so soon forgot? how dares thou sin after this rate and rob a woman of her
liberty which thou hast sworn to defend at least, if not procure?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You are too hasty Pisauro, without question he will give her all she wishes and the Reformation askes.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: No, you're deceiv'd Sir, though I was English when a batchelour, I'le be a true Italian and my self, when married. I value her credit and my quiet too much to do otherwise.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Then may all Cupids curses light upon thee.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I dare venture ten times more than that blind boy is able to inflict for such a prize, farewel Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, stay and take all with you, may'st thou be impotent in th' height of all thy wishes.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Be jealous, yet never have a cause.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Run mad with dotage and she scorn thee.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Leave, leave I shall grow fat with cursing.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Thou shalt have enough to burst thee then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: May'st thou have Sons, yet never dare to own them, and they beg their bread.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: May thy daughters be so rank to doat on Monkeys.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: May'st thou live to see all this and hang thy self.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I'm pleas'd to see you envy me; and you have cause, for I shall have delights lawful and wholesome too, when I shall meet you trayling of your legs after you or walking upon crutches with but one nose among you. Adieu laughs or will you go with me and believe your eyes?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We will, lead us; and if fair means don't, force shall.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Come Tutor, as we go I'le tell you my design which you must further.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come 'tis in vain to whine, I will not sleep till I have don't.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: You may be deceiv'd for all this yet.
Courage Sister he begins to yawn already.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p:
I'le see whether a Nunnery and a husband can reclaim
you. Nor shall it go much better with your gewgaw Brother. Are you so rampant, you must make a decoy of my own house to catch your wild fowl in?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Give me some little time for to prepare my self.

sp.speaker: Ca
sp.p: Oh you have done that to the purpose, sinner enough to spend the rest of your life in penitence.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: There's another, it will do.
Pray Sir let me live there and bear her company.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No, though you're both naught, I'de willingly keep one of you to breed on, and it shall be you, a Nunnery will give you too much liberty.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: If I must marry give me leave to chose.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Your choice is likely to be good by the company you keep; but I've provided for you, you shall be kept so close you scarcely shall have light enough yawns to read your prayers by.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: That's too cruel, I would pray for you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: It must be backward then; thy youth is all the reason I can give to think thou'rt not a witch; O' my conscience thou can'st fly, but I'le have your wings clipt, and you put into a Cage for better security.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: They have been wild indeed yawns took I what care I could.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Why do'st thou yawn so, thou infects me too.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: You see Ladies though I have no teeth I can find my tongue.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: I prophesie that you will lose it yet e're long, for wronging of the innocent.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Welcome Son, I was waiting for you.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I've brought my friends along, the Gallants of the Reformation, to see me happy and to take their leave.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I shall take care to reform my daughters from keeping them company, yawns you have spoiled a Son of mine too among you

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Who do you speak Sir to?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: To you all.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: To you Sir, since you are so brisk yawns this is the very Royster that gag'd and bound me Sir.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Let's look, thou gap'st as if thou had'st a gag there yet.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: How is't Sir, you look not well; your eyes are heavy too.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Only a little weary and faint yawns with chiding of these wicked girles.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Wil't please you sit? A Chair there.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: How is't Sir?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Pray take away this gaping woman yawns and let us fin— fin— fin— ish—

sp.speaker: Nurs.
sp.p: Wil't please you to have a little yawns cordial water, or yawns some aqua mi— mirabilis, or— or.

div.stage: Falls a sleep leaning on Cam.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Believe me Madam, it proceeded all from Love.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I must obey Sir.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: He's fast, he's fast Madam.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Then I am free.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: And I shall scarcely say my Prayers in a Nunnery to day; how lovingly they sleep!

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: How's this! you have not murdered him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nothing but a gentle sleep Sir, which does our business as well.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Was you so ignorant to think wee'd let thee carry it thus?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: What my wise Coffee-drinker over-reacht?

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: This is beyond all sufferance, what say you Madam? will you refuse me too?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I would not marry without my Fathers leave for all the world.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Send you joy Sir, we believe our own eyes.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: I'le never stay for to be baited thus.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Nay, prethee stay a while, and let me tell you a secret, you'l want news else. We gave this sleeping portion to Camillo and the Nurse, to gain an opportunity of going
out to laugh and dance: Remember Sir: and kept you in discourse till this time, when we were sure it would work, for to prevent your marriage: Do you mark Sir? some few houres hence he wakes, and then you may come again and tell your story.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Yes, and be revenged.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: If you dare make a second triall, this is but purgatory, you know the next punishment.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Sunk in the height of all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Well Gallants, I'le before and leave you to wait upon the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But whither prithee?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: To Lysandro's here hard by.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: He's not at home.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: But his wife is, that's as good.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay 'tis much better; does your furnace stand there?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Ladies I shall wait you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Whose within there?
Pray Tutor call some body to carry these in and set them warm.

div.stage: Enter Servants, carry off Cam. Nurse.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now have I a strange design comes into my head.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You know Gallants I promised to reform the old men; what if we should shave Camillo, head and chin, and let him wake in a great white wig?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: For heavens sake, that would make him irreconcileable.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No, No, that's driving on too fast, we're pretty well advanced.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I only do propose. Come Ladies shall we go?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I wish our mirth ends well.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Fie Sister to think of that before it does begin.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I vow to gad Madam nothing but an affair of this moment and that—

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Oh Sir you have honoured me.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Oh Gad Madam the honour— and but that I know your goodness Dear Madam— let me perish but— one minute returns me as much your humble Servant, as— your Servant Madam, your servant.

div.head: Scena Secunda.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I'me glad to find your new gallant tickles so.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: He would make a Nun laugh that's just profest, and that's the sorrowful'st laughs time I can think of; all I wonder at is, that I live.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What's the matter? did he stand upon his head or conjure, that he's such a miracle?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I know not what you mean by conjuring, but all the juglers at a Carnival have not so many tricks.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I must get some musick for thee, O' my conscience thou art stung wench, prithee leave and speak.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Why Madam all the Painters since the art was found out, ne're drew half the postures he was in, in less than half an hour, he goes as puppets do by wiers. Pray Madam have a little patience and I'le shew you. After a shrug and a salute, which he tells me is the new mode, he gives his little whalebone a twirle or two.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Well then I make my curtsy.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Right Madam, then the Divel refuse him. But mine's the pleasant'st seat in Venice, and that gives him opportunity to take as strut or two to view the room; but all this time the wig and shirt is order'd, and as soon as e're the looking glass was spied, out comes the comb, and I had twenty tunes begun and never ended, or ended and ne're begun.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But what must I do all this while?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Admire Madam, then the posture's alter'd, and off goes the glove which shows the diamond ring, and out comes the gold Watch, which must be placed with art, for fear the chain hang not out enough to be seen.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Thou'rt a Divel to abuse him thus.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Next he approaches and knows I am a wit by the chosing of my ribbons, and rails at the poor Country Madam, for making him sweat in Summer with her hot colours. Next subject of discourse was the alteration of the mode in Laces; commends my work, and calls all the stitches by their proper names, and in the midst of this begins a new tune, swears 'tis good, and from thence takes occasion to run over all the Plays and his acquaintance with the Poets.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Could'st thou desire better company?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Nay he has not done yet Madam; then he talks o're all the women of the town, and how Tom such a one, had turn'd off Betty, and Dick such another kept Mall, and call'd them all by their names as freely as if he had been Pimp to all the company.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And ten to one their names is all he knows them by, but you must know 'tis modish and a great attainment.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: At last when he came into the discourse of travel, I concluded we should ne're have done, but all o'th' suddain he makes me three or four cringes of several fashions, begs leave for to dispatch some great affair (which I suppose was to look upon some new wig he had bespoke) and hee'd be here immediatly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: And what dost thou think of him after all this?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: You must needs guess Madam, as of a most egregious Fop. I'm beholden to Pisauro for his good wishes.
And here he comes in time for to receive my thanks.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I am ashamed to hear thee talk thus, what blessing can'st thou imagine greater than a husband that's a fool and rich?

sp.speaker: Lel
sp.p: Heaven forbid Madam.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
Thou'rt an Idiot: Is't not better to have him busy
himself with points and ribbons, toys and laces, than to be alwayes grave and melancholy, which in a while will make him jealous too and mark your very looks.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: 'Tis odds but that you're lock't up, and see the Sun but once a twelvemonth, and have no other company but some old woman that does the office of a deaths head and puts you in mind of dying.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You see what arts I'me forc'd to use to cheat Lysander with, such a man as this will manage all your purpose himself.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I will be rul'd by you Madam.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: 'Twas well said, how did he behave himself?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I have had that at full, no more now I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: How did you carry it?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I took your directions, and had as many modish postures as I then could think on, sometimes thus, then thus.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: That must needs take him, did he speak any thing of Love?
sp.stage: She acts several ridiculous conceited postures.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I can't tell how to answer you, or what his way of courtship is when he's in earnest, but he commended me as if I was to sell, grip'd my hand and kist it, talk't of the power of love and women, and all the time screw'd up and down as if he had been netled.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: These are good signs, I shall know all as soon as e're I see him: Pacheco sings within. heark! I believe he's coming, yes 'tis he I hear him sing, pray withdraw; the Ladies will be here immediately.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Save you Sir, you're got off alive I see.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes faith, and that's all; hang me Pisauro if she is not the first woman that has moved me on this side England.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: I thought 'twas she must nick your humor.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Take me if she has not wit too and demean, understands address and all that.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: This character from you will raise her in my esteem.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: You must give me leave to understand a little.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: You are the only judge, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Believe me she has the true Court air, takes every thing that's new and modish. I'le swear to you, I have sometimes cast an afternoon away, run through all my common places of discourse, and at the last been thought ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: You must meet with women that have been barbarous then.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No Sir, 'twas want of breeding and converse, not one in ten that has the least of it. Alas Sir, there's a particular mine, languishing look, and je ne scay quoy, as we say, and all this she has in perfection. Take me, if I don't think there is a perfect sympathy between us. But this thing of friends.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: You are Melancholy of the suddain.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No Sir, I am only contriving something to advance our Reformation, and to make us perfect.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: It will do.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: And it shall be hard but I'le out-do you all.

div.stage: Enter Anto. Pedro, Tutor, Juliana, Mariana, Ismena, Lelia.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: All the entertainment I can promise is your freedom, Gallants, and that you're in a house where you have all things at command.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: There's nothing can be added Madam.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Now you honour me, I have invited you to an English treat, Ladies, room and musick, you bring the mirth and company with you.
Some Chairs there.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I have been so rude as to encrease your company without your knowledge, Sir, to day I swore a stranger and invited him, he promised me to bring his Mistriss too.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: The least acquaintance Sir with you must challenge welcome.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I know you'l like his humor, 'tis free beyond any thing I ever met on this side the Alpes. I in a moment found that we were made for one another's company.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: That free humor which you speak of brings a welcome with it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: This looks well, we were made for this.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Methinks we begin to live now, we did but dream away our time before, Sister.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: It was not half so pleasant; but now you speak of dreaming, Heaven keep my Father fast.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I resolve to think of nothing here but mirth.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Bravely said Madam. Come let's be frolick then.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: My Tutor has provided us a dance was made to set off his new last Play in England.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray let us have it then, ' tmust be as proper here as there.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I'le step out and get it ready.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Will it please you sit Ladies? Some wine there.

div.stage: They go to set two women together.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Two women together! let us never begin our Reformation with such a sin, come I'le teach you better, and as Master will begin an English health. Here, here stand a Lady and a Gallant. Now Madam a health to my Mis and your Gallant.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: Here Sir, here's a health to my Gallant and your Mis.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Right, Right, fill it about.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: So now all hands.

lg.l: Fill round the healths good natur'd and free,
No custom our joyes shall defer.
Each Lady has her Gallant, each man has his Mis,
Let us kiss, let us kiss, A la mode d'Angle terre.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: If this be an English custom, 'tis a mighty kissing country, this is too much.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Right! I knew she that liked it best would be the first that should complain.

div.stage: They all sit a man and a woman.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Strike up there.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Come Sir have you never another health?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: A thousand.

div.stage: As he's going to drink, Enter Lysander, Emilia.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Shall I keep my resolution?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Yes prithee do for my sake.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Dear heart! I wish autority can bid you welcome now.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, but I can make my self so.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: 'Slife thou hast undone us man, why this is husband to the Lady in whose house we are.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: What then he's sworn, and 'tis as common for a wife to make a ball without her husbands knowledge, as for a Nun to say her Prayers; is't not Tutor?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Yes Sir, 'tis nothing, or with their konwledge either: Lysander all this time compliments the Ladies. More, the good man rather than his wife shall lose a kiss, takes her by the hand and tells the next man that comes, my wife Sir, and then she's slaver'd round the company.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This must be Lysander, what can this come to?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: At the worst we must resolve to carry off the Ladies safe.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: 'Twas kindly done to comfort up the widdow Gentlemen, come ne're disturb your selves, I'm a sworn Brother.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Resolve to carry't off briskly, there's no other way left.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Art ' come dearest? ten thousand welcomes, you ee what shift I'm forc'd to make to comfort me in solitude; but all's too little for to make amends for one Lysander.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Dear rogue thou can'st not think how much I wanted thee too, you see what paultry shift I was forced to make.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: She's wondrous fair, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, though I allow all freedom with my wife, you know the English fashion is to keep my Mistris to my self.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I beg your pardon Sir, 'twas well remembred.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I see you're angry, but I was forced to seek to ease my grief by any way when you was absent.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p:
Not I, ne're trouble your self to make this excuse, I
love this mirth; but prithee chuck tell me, which of these is thy Gallant? or do they take't by turns, come prithee do, good faith I count my self beholden to him, he eases me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I see no faithfulness can e're oblige you.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Now thou art too modest, for shame Pisauro own her, I know I pay for all that finery.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Nay we'l be man and wife still in any place but bed, and that want you have provided for your self, ne're trouble your self. If you do more than e're I could Pisauro, and she prove fruitful, I promise here to be a Godfather. If I have the same success here, I expect the like kindness from you Juliana.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: This is true love.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Now our Reformation goes forward in good earnest.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: It amazes me; would I were free from hence once.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Come, come, Gentlemen, be frolick, you seem troubled; Is not this better than slitting of noses or a stab Gentlemen? we can call chuck and joy and twenty such pretty names still, as well as the very best of them.
Nay faith Ladies one dance more for my sake, I shall grieve that I disturbed you else.
Musick there

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Now be but pleas'd to take a small collation in the next room, and I shall believe you think your selves welcome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We'l wait you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Yet I'me impatient till I'me gone.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: There's no danger Madam.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I fear none Sir.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Let me perish else.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: You make me blush Sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Let me die if any thing's more serious.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Come how is't joy?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Thank thee Dearest.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.l: The world may laugh, and names of scorn invent,
But to be Cuckolds nothing if content.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: TIs strange that we can fasten no such thing as honor upon the Sex, whereas a man's lies every where. Twinge him by the nose, his honour's there, and presently must be redeem'd.
Kick him, and 'tis remov'd to's backside, and must be engaged.
But this of woman-kind is really nothing. For if one unmarried chance to kick up her heeles, the reproach returns upon the family.
Or if a wife prove gamesome more than ordinary, shee's thought a wit, and cunning; and 'tis the husband's branded with the name of scorn.

Now should I go kill Pisauro to redeem my honour: and if I do, die honourably by an Executioner, or fly my Country: Or if I fall my self, they'l cry there died a silly cuckold, worth the while. I thank my stars I'me less nice in these points, and have found out a safer way.
Welcome dearest, I was sending for thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I fear'd you might be angry.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: What for such petty faults?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay now you speak as if you did not think me honest.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Not honest? Why you know I have no reason to the contrary: Prithee no more on't, I wou'd make a bargain with thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: With me Sir? What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: In short, what is't you're willing to take a year for alimony?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: This is harder than the first.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p:
'Tis that, that must be understood, for I resolve to carry on my part in the Reformation by this means. Consult
your self and friends, for I would have you live in credit still.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Pray Sir be plain.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Why thus.

Write me down so much for cloaths, so much for diet, and lodgings: something too for pleasure I'le allow; 'tis the saving English way, and 'tis but reasonable when a wife proves false, she should be stinted, and the overplus should keep a Miss. Come, come, I'me out of my frollick humor now, and am serious.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Now you are cruel, will you quite ruine me?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: No such matter, I'le be as civil too as any man, only retrench some small sums you us'd to spend in charitable uses, as fourty pound to such a Nunnery, aliàs for a new suit; twenty unto such a Monastery, aliàs a new Wigg: why should you be lavish in your good deeds? There's scarce a Covent in the town but's bound to pray for you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Pray pardon me, you us'd to say you loved me.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I pardon you with all my heart; but I'le take care that you shall sin no more with my purse, nor let Pisauro brave it with my wealth, as I know he does; come, it is in vain for to deny.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay if you grow angry once, Emilia does so to; why should not I have the same liberty?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: There are some thirty and odd reasons to the contrary, besides the common practice; but that which must satisfie you is, I will not have it so, and 'tis in my power to hinder it, remember what I say.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Oh Pisauro, we're undone.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Come, no such matter, I have overheard it all, if Pacheco marry Lelia, as 'tis almost out of doubt, this sore will soon be heal'd; besides my fortune's not so very low, but I can live, and your allowance will be fair, I dare promise.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: But will you still love me?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: I'le double it if possible.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: All that troubles me is, I shall want my wealth to serve you with.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Prithee no more, we lose time, Lelia be careful not to seem too coy, but if he comes to steal you let him carry off the prize: Friends, or the grave will soon reconcile Camillo: I must thither and see how affairs go, come courage Madam we can never want.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I fear nothing but losing my Gallant.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: I'me resolv'd to make sure of mine.

div.head: Scena Secunda.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Am I exact in every thing? the colours suited? and my cloaths cut with the modish air?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: To a thought: You see what 'tis to imploy a Taylor knowing in the fashion. There's nothing like your French cut Sir, you shall have a country Gentleman come to town, and throw away a years revenue on a suit on purpose to be laught at, hang me if a Livery been't more creditable.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Then there's much in the wearing of them too, why here now, what would this belt be valued at, without I wore it? Now it imploys the hands, and gives a grace to all the gate.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I joy to see you thus improved, you may read to me shortly. Oh dear Pupil.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Then there's the cock of the hat, tying of the shirt, fashions of crevats, the wearing of a Wig that's friz'd or curl'd, things that alter daily, and that these poor fools can ne're pretend to.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: You amaze me Sir, I shall grow proud of my success.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Take me if I had not rather pass a judgment of a man, from a shake a la mode, wearing of a Mistresses faver, or the tying of a knot (there's a perfect Genius shown in that) than from a months converse.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: You have reason Sir; these are the things men travel for, trust me you may be a pattern to the very Author of the fashion. Nay if you're once resolved I know you must needs carry her, but—

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: No more objections good Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Not I Sir, I see she's fair, believe her vertuous and a fortune, but yet—

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: More but's yet? now I begin to think thou enviest me, 'tis certain I will do something shall make me chief; truth is, Lysander bid fair for the command, but at the last I've found it, and defie him, and all the rest, to think of Conquest.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: May I know it?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Yes on condition you'l not speak a word to hinder my design.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Since you are so resolute I engage.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Then thus. I will to Lelia thus drest as I am, which certainly must do't, and without the least enquiry after fortune, or consent of friends marry her for love; the height of Gallantry, and top of Reformation, hah?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I may Sir.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I may go with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: No, I'le have the honor of the action my self, when I return expect me conqueror.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: No doubt of that, you'l find but little opposition.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: I can but think when 'tis done what pleasures I shall have, and blest occasions of new words; As, my Joy, my chuck, my dear, my sweet honey-comb, and she answers in as good a stile; for I resolve to teach her all the English words. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Send you a fair wind, I've gold depends upon your good success.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Well met Tutor, where's Pacheco? we must not let him cool.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: There's no fear: he just now left me, with a Resolution to conclude before he will return.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Then we're happy: his swearing of Lysander was unlucky.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: It must be pardon'd, 'twas perfect zeal and ignorance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Save ye Gentlemen: what news from Camillo, Tutor?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: They were both fast within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: 'Tis much about the time they are to wake.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Shall we beg a favor from you then Sir?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: You may command it Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis that you'd watch my Father, and give us notice when he stirs.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I fly to serve you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twas bravely carryed by Lysander.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That, that pleas'd me was, he nickt the Reformation too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: To a thought: There if the women be displeased, 'tis but finding a pretence of quarrel, sue their husbands, and the law gives them the thirds of the Estate to keep Gallants with.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: I can hardly recover my self though I know I'me out of danger: I would have parted with the little of my Estate to any man breathing for a new Song.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith at the best 'twas but a lease, and that fairly forfeited to the Lord too.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: What will you take for't now it's renew'd Pisauro?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Not renewed upon so good termes as you imagine; but I'le not part with it, whilst the ground bears any crop.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Tis strange the very being women should oblige us to dissemble thus.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: You see 'tis true, for my part I do confess I love and would give all the world to marry my Antonio.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.p: I Pedro. Know 'tis the only remedy for our misfortunes, yet must not let them know it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fie Ladies not out of your fright yet!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Yes Sir we were talking of a greater danger; for
though I'me naturally devout, I don't love to say my prayers on force.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: And though I have no hatred against mankind, yet to have one thrust upon me thus, goes a little against the hair.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We have proposed a way, that will prevent both dangers, would you follow it.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I run the same hazard of a husband.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I one worse than that, of being Nun.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Why Madam, can you think it better to trifle time away in telling beads, and change your youth and briskness for Melancholy looks and wrinckles?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And you resolve to sigh away your life some three stories high, make complaints, and talk to the men it'h ' Arras? That must be your fortune if you wed Leandro.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Suppose all this true, how can you have the confidence to ask us for to marry you? Is it necessary we must break our necks to avoid drowning? Or to shun my fathers making us slaves go shackle up our selves?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As for liberty, you shall make your own propositions.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Which you will keep religiously until you've married us, and then break at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: How can you imagine to avoid this danger?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Pugh, that we'l think on when it comes, at present we are free.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: But to be serious Ladies be your own Judges, is there not something in the Society of men you much desire?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Confest, but ne're will purchase it at such a rate as marriage.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Why then you must resolve to be kind without it. 'Tis a hard case if you neither lead nor drive.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That we must be stretcht upon a rack, for no fault too, without the least hope of ease.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: What can you desire more than this freedom?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Very much: That is the very thing destroyes our hopes, were you but simpring, mimping, bridling Ladies, you were sure prize; those sort of cattel are so little us'd to speak, they think it modesty not to deny you.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Or what do you think of a down demure look?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That never fails neither, I always challenge them, and what they mean for bashfulness, conclude a certain sign of guilt.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: You're obliging Gentlemen, there's half womankind condemn'd already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then there's your devout souls, that sigh and whine, have something of Religion in their very gate; and never speak but in a tone of zeal and purity.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Pox on them, I must be hungry indeed to feed there; they are too common, and usually belong to a whole fraternity: If they can but learn to call their sins by new names, they pass for vertues; and she that sins deepest is the truest Saint.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, no, they're your brisk Ladies that are the hardest conquest. 'Tis true you give us so much freedom, we can't find confidence to ask more, yet when we cast it all up it signifies— just nothing.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Or if we do venture to ask, 'tis but lost labour, you'l never understand us, but wheadle't off with a laugh or some odd story.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen we're beholden to you that our Honor's safe in your opinions.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: And that acknowledgment is all the recompence we're like to have.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For all I can perceive Sir.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: But consider a little: is there no little inclinations, no beatings here— Madam more than ordinary?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: No Sir I can find no such matter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But suppose that to your freedom I should offer that, which uses to be sweeter to your Sex, Revenge too?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Revenge would do something could I get shut of you once, but I swear you're grown so troublesome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In short then, Madam, you resolve to lose both, desert the publick cause, and—

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I have no natural in-bred hatred to your person; and Revenge does tempt a little. But—
Let me die, if I can make objections, I shall hold out no longer.

div.stage: Enter Antonio's Boy in womans cloaths.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Whom do you seek Lady?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Antonio Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Your Servant Madam, hang me if I knew you at the first glance. Thou com'st luckily: be sure not to be amaz'd at whatsoe're I say or do, but answer me in my own strain.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Who is this? they're mighty well acquainted Sir methinks.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Faith Madam I can't guess, she's very fair.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: But well: I know some Ladies will not be ashamed to shew their faces in her company. Would I could blast that little beauty that she has.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I thought our loves would ne're admit of jealousie, but thou art too kind.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'Tis you have made me so, I were ingrateful Sir indeed should I not endeavour to return your love.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: How's this? Return his love? then I am wretched.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: You seem angry Madam.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Not I Sir, 'tis not in the power of man to make me so, Aside but that woman does.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You think me Sir too free I fear.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No dearest, our old love may challenge this and more.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: May they poison thee.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I smell it, 'tis Antonio's Boy he courts. And she must love by her concern. Now I'le strike home.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You have your story ready for Camillo.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And you'l not fail to meet me there Dearest?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I shall ne're deny my self a happiness.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But are you sure my Sister will be found so easy as to yield?

sp.speaker: Ped
sp.p: I only beg the promise that you'l follow her example.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I may have confidence enough in her to grant,
and yet shew little kindness. Aside at worst it saves my blushes.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That little's all I ask, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'le only end a formal compliment or two.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Treacherous base man!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pisauro, shall I beg you would conduct this Lady?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: You honor me with the trust.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Will you go Sister?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You'l give me leave to wait on you Madam.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: No Sir, you have your hands full I see already, and may spare your formal compliments. Would you fail your assignation with so great a beauty?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: As I could wish. She is not ugly Madam.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I don't intend a quarrel on the subject. 'Tis indifferent to me what she is.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I see it is Madam; nor could you blame me for courting her, when I found you so cruel.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I blame you? Why did you not leave Pisauro here, and go your self? there's no body so fond of your company. Come Sister. to Pedro I hope Sir you'l be so kind as to shew us the way home.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay fie Sister part friends. to Pedro You see Sir we are like to meet.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I'le take my fortune Madam, Aside and know I have a sure card to play.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis pretty to fall from the discourse of marriage into this of chiding.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Marriage? I'le rather be shut up with Leandro in a grave, than ever have a thought of you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But I'me sure you will; more, know you must. Nay what is more yet, am confident 'twill be a match.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Now you're impudent. Did I ever shew the least kindness to you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Confest, but this anger makes me think you have had no unkindness for me.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: To vex you, I will confess it true, but add to it, that I hate you now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis very strange, all that you can say, can never make me believ't.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I tell you I should hate my self, should I ever have the least good thought of you. Nay I shall hate all mankind for your sake, scarce spare my Brother for beginning our acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This still confirms me more in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is mad courtship.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: I know it must succeed, for nothing heightens love so much as a misgrounded jealousie.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What if I would promise, I would love no woman besides you? is there no hopes of pardon?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: No, I scorn it now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: If I swear I never did love a woman?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Nothing. I know it false, and if I doated on you, should hate you for this lie.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Ladies, you must thist for yourselves, and that with speed: your Father is awake, has sent for Leandro; and to the Senate, that he may force you home, where e're he finds you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You know your old retreat.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I'le die first.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I'le be as good as my word, and follow my Sister.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now I begin to find I'me wretched.
If this unlucky woman had not come I had been happy.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: And I more miserable far than now. Come Sister let's fly any whither from these men.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray stay Madam, since I have work't you to a height, and am confirm'd you love me by this jealousie, know that Lady was my Boy, drest in that habit to procure your liberty. I knew I had no other way to make this blest discovery. Will you yet give me leave?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I am worse angry than before to be betrai'd by this trick.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Consider Madam you'd better do't, I'le make good my promise, liberty and Revenge.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: No, no such matter: it may be I'le vouchsafe to hear your story out.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: A minutes stay will ruine all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What do you resolve on Sister?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Only that I will not have Leandro.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: My hopes are fair yet Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You know the grounds on which they stand.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Away I say. I easily guess where this quarrel will end.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Never plead for them, to be made the talk and story of all the town, Sung in Ballads, for't will come to that; The careful father gull'd, or old Camillo's dream, I can, nor will hear no more.

sp.speaker: Lean.
sp.p: Threatning will but make them fly your fury: whereas a promise of pardon brings them with submission into your power, and then you may contrive their punishment.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Contrive? do you hear me?

For the first I'le have a dungeon so dark and streight that she shall grope the way unto her mouth, and have no other air but sighs to live on. The second you should never wed, did I not believe you would invent some lasting terrors unto all that are or shall be Wives.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Trust me with that: but first it's necessary, I seek'em out, and bring them home.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: If they refuse, use force; the Senate cannot deny their power to so just designs.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: I hope we shall not need it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Never was man at my age so rid.
To be rock't asleep like a great Baby, whilst they are all a revelling. Well, I shall meet with these dap-chicks: That Jay my son, with the Owl his Tutor, and if I do—
Hah! who have we here?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You may wonder at a strangers rudeness Sir, and why a woman thus intrudes.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: By my troth so I do, but the Divel's in you all for impudence.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
When you know I have necessity and Justice on
my side, I cannot doubt but you'l relieve my misery.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: A beggar in this garb! be gon, I have no time to hear long stories, nor will to supply your wants.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: To relieve my wants will never make you poorer Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: The right religious Cant to? you know the way, be gon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Pray hear me out, and then I know you will have pitty.
If e're you had a Mother, you owed a duty to, or wife you lov'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis a pretty tone this.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: If you have daughters, as I know you have, whose honor you'd preserve from stain: if any thing that's yet more dear, by all I do conjure you to hear me out.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Now am I such a Coxcomb, that though I know it is a cheat, yet I must listen, come rise and begin then.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: This most unhappy woman that you see, whose little beauty tears and grief have turn'd to ruins, yet was once thought fair, till perjury and all that's false weeps O false Leandro!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: How! was't not Leandro that she nam'd? What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Till he false man by force and treachery, had ravisht all my wealth, and left me thus neglected.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come pray be plain, I'le hear you now with patience.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: As soon as grief will let me Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: There's no trust in woman kind if this be false.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My Father was a Merchant, and accounted rich, his place of living Candy, whilst alive, Heaven rest his soul.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: This must be true, it moves me too. His name?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Fabricio. When the enemy approacht our walls, he was commander for this State, and in their Services lost his life. 'Twas that unhappy minute, when I saw Leandro first, whose seeming goodness might have tempted one more wife, than miserable me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Pray on. I long to hear thee out.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
In short, my Mother trusted him with all concerns,
her wealth, her self, and me. He liv'd a while a faithful Guardian. And I (for it must out) too soon lov'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Your name Lady?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Fabia, in a word.

He promis'd to convey our family, and riches to this town, did so, but in the voyage, after a thousand vows of Marriage, which we could not then consummate, stole my honor, and ever since hath left me to my grief.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Blest discovery, trust me now I pitty thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: If you pitty, help me Sir and save your self, this same Leandro still must needs be false, and will you throw away a Virgin on a perjur'd man? And if she marries him, I'me lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: If I find this story true, I'le promise that your Father's name's Fabritio, your's Fabia.
Hold, I think I hear him coming.
sp.stage: Enter Leandro, Antonio, Pedro, Mariana, Ismena.
sp.p: Away, away, I have nothing to say to you. Nor you neither, you may return.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We have business Sir that much concerns you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Let it be what it will I have no leisure: if you will stay, come not near my daughters, but go you to that corner of the room, you to this; so the Divel's in you if you play tricks at this distance. My business is with Leandro.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Your Pleasure Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Only a little scruple, I remember I have sworn, never to match my daughter with a man that had not hazarded his life to serve the State.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: That can be no Obstacle. I've serv'd it long, and when our Candy was besieged, sent numbers of the infidels to seek their Prophet in the other world. This my friends can witness.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: You knew Fabritio then?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How it works?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p:
Fabritio was my leader Sir, and train'd me up to Arms, many a bold sally has he made, and brought back Victory,
nor did he tamely lose his life, but fell encompass'd with an host of slaughter'd enemies.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Thus far we do agree. How fared it with his wife and daughter Sir? I have heard he left both.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: He did, and both patterns to the Sex. They shar'd the common fortune, and when the town was yielded up set sail for Venice.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Right yet.
How was the daughter call'd?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Fabia. (What can all this mean?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I am confirm'd.
Do you know this Lady?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: No Sir, nor till this minute ever saw her face.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O Perjur'd man! is Fabia so soon forgot? false, false Leandro.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Pray look again.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: May I ne're enjoy the thing I love on earth, or when I die heaven—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: His strong denials make me confident. Consider once again, is not this Fabia?

sp.speaker: Fabia
sp.p: whom you have wrong'd?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Neither Sir if you require oaths.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: If oaths could have obliged, I never had become thus wretched.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Heavens, that e're such impudence should wear the shape of women! wer't thou not so—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come, no threats Sir.
She's in a sanctuary in my house. Take her, and make amends for all your former injuries.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: What injuries? you will distract me Sir, give me but a minute for to clear my self.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: No, I am satisfied already, and will not be cheated, nor let my daughter run her self to certain ruine. I'le in, and fetch the writing you have given.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Hell and Furies.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Save you Sir, how do you like your Island?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: Will you never leave your tortures?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: This is the hell we told you of, if you ventured to sin again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: As for your new discovery I have taken possession, and it's like to be call'd by my name; in short I am married to Ismena, Pedro to Mariana, and this Fabia is the Boy drest up to amuse Camillo.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Here take him, you're so much an Italian, you need not lose your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.p: You shall find me more by my Revenge.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thus far our plot succeeds.

sp.speaker: Boy,
sp.p: do you steal away and get undrest: I would not have Camillo find that cheat yet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He's coming: To our places.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Here, here, where's Leandro?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And Fabia?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes Sir but not together.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Then these must be sent.

Now I have leisure to come to you, Runagates, for though you have escaped this danger, you must not think to go free. I have provided for ye both, 'tis not your powder that can find another remedy, I will not eat nor drink till it's perform'd. I guess your business Gentlemen, but you may spare your pains.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: What can this prove?
We kneel for blessing Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I give it you; but who's this?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: Your Daughter, whilst I call her wife.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Still more wretched? Go fool thou hast undone thy self, and shalt live nor pittied nor relieved by me.
That I should ever be a Father!
But I'le study to forget the name.
These a Nunnery if possible shall save from ruine. In I say.

sp.speaker: Ant. Ped.
sp.p: That we forbid Sir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: What shall I not rule my own family in my own house? In I say.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: They may with justice disobey, they leave their husbands here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Who thus in duty ask your blessing.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Blessing? e'ne the down-right Divel take you all, I am gull'd, cheated, fool'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh Pedro, we can never prosper if a fathers blessing be denied.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Never fear Madam, a little patience reconciles all.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: Joy Gallants. Three weddings in a day? the State can never want Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: There's little joy belongs to me. The Reformation goes on too fast now; for though I like this marrying for love, I hate this damn'd English way of disinheriting.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: What can this mean?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay faith the old Gentleman's strangely angry, prithee try what you can do Lysander, your acquaintance has been great.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I will, I'me confident when once he knows your qualities, he'l think his daughters well bestow'd, and an only Sons pardon is soon obtain'd.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: However it succeed, I'de rather run a thousand dangers than be slave to Leandro's jealousie. This was a brave revenge done like a Master of your Art.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That part of my promise is fulfill'd then; but now 't's too late to bargain for your liberty, you're at my mercy still.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I thought it best to trust you.
I knew a promise was sooner broke, than your good nature turn'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: However of my own accord I here ingage to be true, until I find you false, and then I'le take Lysander's pattern.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p:
Then here I promise for you, that you always shall
be true. I ever lov'd the talk of liberty, more than the thing it self.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: You Mariana, may challenge all the freedom that you'l take.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I shall take the less, for your giving me so much.

sp.speaker: Nurse.
sp.p: I have found my tongue again, and if I don't rail you all deaf—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Say you so, I have the other gag for you.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen, reckon it a considerable piece of Reformation, that we have found out two infallible remedies, to cure an old womans talking.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How is't? where is he?

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: He's come unto himself again, now he considers who you are, and follows me.
Well met Madam, I hope you're pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Since you are so cruel as to part, I must allow you truly noble.

sp.speaker: Lys.
sp.p: I doubt Pisauro some of these fine feathers must molt.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: You're deceived Sir, with these I intend to purchase a rich wife, and pay some of my old scores to Juliana.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Heaven bless you; and if you can live on that, do. But I am so much a Reformer, as not to part with a farthing of money, without settlement, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That shall never breed a difference.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I knew your Father well Antonio; if you prove as well, my daughter's happy.
Your's Pedro, for so I ' me told you're cal'd, is my peculiar friend, and if he likes the match, I will do any thing that's just.
But what can you pretend to, with your Gimcracks and travels, hah?

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p:
I married Sir for love and Virtue, and have heard you say it was your fault (if it may be accounted one)
when you took my Mother; I only follow'd your example.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Well nick't Pupil.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: H'as found my weak side, it must not be denied. Well, you shall be upon your good behavior.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: If it comes to that I know I shall soon win him.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I'le give you Lectures for't to morrow.
My gold's good Sir.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Yes this little Pinnace sailes to fetch it home.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.p: And will bring it too, I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Come you shall all dine with me, we will be so long friends at least.
If two of these adventures come off well, I have made a saving voyage.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I have something to do still, which is the Reforming of you Mounsieur Tutor. Nay never shrink, for one of these things must be subscribed to, either chuse to renounce your interest in the Society.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: That's hard.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Or your pretence to Poetry, and acquaintance with the Muses as you call't.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Harder yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Or engage in three months, to produce a Play which shall have nothing in't borrow'd, nor improbable, nor prophane, nor bawdy.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: This is almost impossible, but yet I'le venture, and if my Play miscarries here, set sail for England, where any one of these qualities will make it famous.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Now it's perfect, Antonio.
sp.l: We're married, yet can know no jealousie.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And Sister we are wives, and yet are free.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Blest Reformation!
sp.l: All's right, we should have nothing left to do,
Could we Reform one English custom too,
That's the damn'd trade of censuring in you.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: HOw do you like our Reformation now?
Come, we're amongst our selves. Here are Wits too. pointing to Pacheco and Tutour.
Or shall's to th' Coffee-house and there debate,
Each take his Chair and Pipe and judg in State?
Lord how they wait a Wit that's fam'd in Town!
He lookes about him with a scornful frown,
Then picks his Favourite out and sits him down.
Take me how is't? Have you seen our new Play?
Yes faith; and how? a half Crown thrown away,
Pox on't he cries, I Droll'd and Slept it out;
'Twas some Raw Fop: Then proudly stares about;
Then shrugs and whispers, laughs, then swears aloud.
The whilst there's silence kept by all the Croud.
At length he nods and cocks, is heard to say,
D— me 'tis true, and thus he damns the Play,
Rises, lookes big and combs, then goes his Way.
'Tis strange to think how absolute they are,
When lookes, half Words and Oathes, destroy or spare.
We can expect no favour; these are known
Foes unto every thing that's not their own.
And rather too, than that shall want applause,
They'l clap themselves and that way gain the cause.
By such like Arts they rule the stage and you,
And what was Favour first, now claim as due.
For shame use your Authority and free
Your selves from these usurpers Tyranny,
Ne're wait their censure more, but let them know
You have the power that they pretended to.
They wheadle you to clap bad plays they write:
To be reveng'd do you clap this to night.
But Ladies you our Author hopes to find
In your own Cause and for your own sakes kind,
Since 'tis the first design of's Poetry
Both how to gain and give you Liberty.
